1004036_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	Tanger Factory Outlet Centers, Inc. and subsidiaries is one of the largest owners and operators of outlet centers in the United States.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	We are a fully-integrated, self-administered and self-managed REIT, which focuses exclusively on developing, acquiring, owning, operating and managing outlet shopping centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P0_S2	As of December 31, 2010 , we owned and operated 31 outlet centers, with a t otal gross leasable area of approximately 9.2 million square feet.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P0_S3	These outlet centers were 98% occupied and contained over 2,000 stores, representing approximately 360 store brands.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P0_S4	We also operated and had partial ownership interests in two outlet centers totaling approximately 948,000 square feet.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	The outlet centers and other assets are held by, and all of our operations are conducted by, Tanger Properties Limited Partnership and subsidiaries.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	The Company owns the majority of the units of partnership interest issued by the Operating Partnership, through its two wholly-owned subsidiaries, the Tanger GP Trust and the Tanger LP Trust.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P2_S1	The Tanger GP Trust controls the Operating Partnership as its sole general partner.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P2_S2	The Tanger LP Trust holds a limited partnership int erest.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P2_S3	The Tanger family, through its ownership of the Tanger Family Limited Partnership, holds the remaining units as a limited partner.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	Stanley K. Tanger, founder of the Company, was the sole general partner of the Tanger Family Limited Partnership from its inception until August 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P3_S1	For further discussion, see Note 24 to the Consolidated Financial Statements filed under Item 15 to this Form 10-K.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	As of December 31, 2010 , the Company, through its ownership of the Tanger GP and Tanger LP Trusts, owned 20,249,017 units of the Operating Partnership and the Tanger Family Limited Partnership owned the remaining 3,033,305 u nits.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P4_S1	Each Tanger Family Limited Partnership unit is exchangeable for four of the Company's common shares, subject to certain limitations to preserve the Company's REIT status.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	Ownership of the Company's common shares is restricted to preserve the Company's status as a REIT for federal income tax purposes.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P5_S1	Subject to certain exceptions, a person may not actually or constructively own more than 4% of our common shares.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P5_S2	We also operate in a manner intended to enable us to preserve our status as a REIT, including, among other things, making distributions with respect to our outstanding common shares equal to at least 90% of our taxable income each year.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Company is a North Carolina corporation and the Operating Partnership is a North Carolina partnership, which were formed in 1993.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P6_S1	Our executive offices are currently located at 3200 Northline Avenue, Suite 360, Greensboro, North Carolina, 27408 and our telephone number is (336) 292-3010.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P6_S2	Our website can be accessed at www.tangeroutlet.com.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P6_S3	A copy of our 10-Ks, 10-Qs, 8-Ks and any amendments thereto can be obtained, free of charge, on our website as soon as reasonably practicable after we file such material with, or furnish it to, the Securities and Exchange Commission (the "SEC").The information found on, or otherwise accessible through, our website is not incorporated into, and does not form a part of, this annual report on Form 10-K or any other report or document we file with or furnish to the SEC.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	In November 2010, we opened our newest Tanger outlet center in Mebane, North Carolina 100% occupied.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	The new center contains approximately 319,000 square foot and approximately 80 outlet tenants.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P7_S2	The total cost for the center was approximately $64.9 million and was funded by operating cash flows and amounts available under our unsecured lines of credit.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	During 2010, we began execution of a redevelopment plan for our Hilton Head I, South Carolina center.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	The plan included a complete demolition of the existing 162,000 square foot center originally acquired in 2003.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P8_S2	The center, which is scheduled to re-open the first weekend of April 2011, will contain approximately 176,000 square feet as well as four outparcel pads.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P8_S3	The total incremental cost for the redeveloped center is expected to be approximately $43.0 million and will be funded by operating cash flows and amounts available under our unsecured lines of credit.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	As of the date of this filing, we are in the initial study period for three potential new development sites located in League City (Houston), Texas; Scottsdale, Arizona and West Phoenix, Arizona.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P9_S1	There can be no assurance that these sites will ultimately be developed.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P9_S2	We expect that these projects, if realized, would be primarily funded by amounts available under our unsecured lines of credit but could also be funded by other sources of capital, such as collateralized construction loans or public debt and equity offerings.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P9_S3	We may also consider the use of additional operational or developmental joint ventures.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	In January 2 011, we announced that we entered into a letter of intent with RioCan Real Estate Investment Trust to form an exclusive joint venture for the acquisition, development and leasing of sites across Canada that are suitable for development or redevelopment as outlet shopping centers similar in concept and design to those within our existing U.S. portfolio.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	Any projects developed will be co-owned on a 50/50 basis and will be branded as Tanger Outlet Centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P10_S2	We have agreed to provide leasing and marketing services to the venture and RioCan will provide development and property management services.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P10_S3	It is the intention of the joint venture to develop as many as 10 to 15 outlet centers in larger urban markets and tourist areas across Canada, over a five to seven year period.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	The typical size of a Tanger Outlet Center is approximately 350,000 square feet dependent on the individual market and tenant demand.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	Assuming these parameters are suitable and materialize in Canada, the overall investment of the joint ven ture is anticipated to be as high as $1 billion, on a fully built out basis,.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	There can be no assurance that the joint venture will be consummated, or even if the joint venture is consummated that the current plans of the joint venture will be realized.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	In June 2010, the Operating Partnership completed a public offering of $300.0 million of 6.125% senior notes due 2020 (the "2020 Notes").
1004036_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	The 2020 Notes pay interest semi-annually and were priced at 99.310% of the principal amount to yield 6.219% to maturity.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	Net proceeds from the offering, after deducting the underwriting discount and offering expenses, were approximately $295.5 million.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P14_S1	We used the net proceeds from the sale of the 2020 Notes to (i) repay our $235 million unsecured term loan due in June 2011, (ii) pay approximately $6.1 million to terminate two interest rate swap agreements associated with the term loan, (iii) repay borrowings under our unsecured lines of credit and (iv) for general working capital purposes.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	In November 2010, the Operating Partnership entered into a $385.0 million syndicated unsecured revolving line of credit (the "Syndicated Line").
1004036_11_ITEM1_P15_S1	In addition to the Syndicated Line, the Operating Partnership simultaneously entered into a $15.0 million cash management line of credit with Bank of America, N.A. (the "Cash Management Line"), providing total revolving line capacity of $400.0 million.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P15_S2	The Cash Management Line's terms are substantially the same as the Syndicated Line, including maturity date.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	The Syndicated Line replaces our previous $325.0 million in bilateral lines of credit that were scheduled to mature between June and August 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	The Syndicated Line, together with the Cash Management Line, represents an increase in line capacity of more than 20%.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	Through an accordion feature, the maximum borrowing capacity on the Syndicated Line may be increased to up to $500.0 million under certain circumstances.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P16_S3	The maturity date of the new lines is November 29, 2013, and we have an option to extend the lines for one year.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P16_S4	As of the date of this filing, based on the Operating Partnership's long-term debt rating, the lines bear interest at a spread over LIBOR of 1.90% and require the payment of an annual facility fee of 0.40% on the total committed amount.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	In December 2010, the Company completed the redemption of all of its outstanding 7.5% Class C Cumulative Preferred Shares.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	The initial redemption price was $25.00 per share, plus all accrued and unpaid dividends up to and including the redemption date, for a total redemption price of $25.198 per share.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P17_S2	Total cash paid to redeem the shares, plus accrued dividends, was $75.6 million.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	In October 2010, Stanley K. Tanger, founder of the Company and member of the Board of Directors, passed away.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P18_S1	Mr. Tanger ceded the role of Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer in 2009, but remained a Director of the Company until his passing.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P18_S2	His legacy lives on and is carried forward by everyone at Tanger Outlet Centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	In August 2010, Thomas E. McDonough joined our management team as Executive Vice-President of Operations.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P19_S1	Mr. McDonough brings nearly 30 years of REIT management, leasing, acquisition and development experience to the Company.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	In September 2010, Thomas R. Reddin was added as a member of the Company's Board of Directors and the Operating Partnership's Board of Trustees.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P20_S1	Mr. Reddin brings over 30 years of consumer marketing and e-commerce experience to the Board.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	In January 2011, Kevin M. Dillon, Senior Vice Presiden t - Construction and Development, announced his resignation effective in April 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P21_S1	Mr. Dillon served in different construction and development related capacities for over 17 years with the Company.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	Outlets are manufacturer-operated retail stores that sell primarily first quality, branded products at significant discounts from regular retail prices charged by department stores and specialty stores.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	Outlet centers offer numerous advantages to both consumers and manufacturers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P22_S2	Manufacturers selling in outlet stores are often able to charge customers lower prices for brand name and designer products by eliminating the third party retailer.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P22_S3	Outlet centers also typically have lower operating costs than other retailing formats, which enhance the manufacturer's profit potential.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	Outlet centers enable manufacturers to optimize the size of production runs while continuing to maintain control of their distribution channels.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	In addition, outlet centers benefit manufacturers by permitting them to sell out-of-season, overstocked or discontinued merchandise without alienating department stores or hampering the manufacturer's brand name, as is often the case when merchandise is distributed via discount chains.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	We believe that outlet centers will continue to present attractive opportunities for capital investment in the long-term.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	We further believe, based upon our contacts with present and prospective tenants that many companies will continue to utilize the outlet concept as a profitable distribution vehicle.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P24_S2	However, due to present economic conditions and the potential for increased competition from other developers announcing plans to develop outlet centers, new developments or expansions may not provide as high of an initial return on investment as has been historically achieved.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	Each of our outlet centers carries the Tanger brand name.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	We believe that national manufacturers and consumers recognize the Tanger brand as one that provides outlet shopping centers where consumers can trust the brand, quality and price of the merchandise they purchase directly from the manufacturers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	As one of the original participants in this industry, we have developed long-sta nding relationships with many national and regional manufacturers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	Because of our established relationships, we believe we are well positioned for the long-term.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	Our outlet centers range in size from 24,619 to 729,475 square feet and are typically located at least 10 miles from major department stores and manufacturer-owned, full-price retail stores.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P27_S1	Manufacturers prefer these locations so that they do not compete directly with their major customers and their own stores.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	Many of our outlet centers are located near tourist destinations to attract tourists who consider shopping to be a recreational activity.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P28_S1	Additionally, our centers are often situated in close proximity to interstate highways that provide accessibility and visibility to potential customers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	As of February 1, 2011, we had a diverse tenant base comprised of approximately 360 different well-known, upscale, national designer or brand name concepts, such as Polo Ralph Lauren, Saks Fifth Avenue - Off Fifth, Calvin Klein, Ann Taylor, GAP, Banana Republic, Old Navy, Juicy, Kate Spade, Lucky Brand Jeans, Reebok, Tommy Hilfiger, Abercrombie Fitch, Eddie Bauer, Coach Leatherware, Brooks Brothers, BCBG, Michael Kors, Nike and others.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	Most of the outlet stores are directly operated by the respective manufacturer.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	No single tenant (includin g affiliates) accounted for 10% or more of our combined base and percentage rental revenues during 2010, 2009 or 2008.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P31_S1	As of December 31 2010, no single tenant, including all of its store concepts, accounted for more than 8.4% of our leasable square feet or 6.6% of our combined base and percentage rental revenues.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P31_S2	Because our typical tenant is a large, national manufacturer, we generally do not experience any material losses with respect to rent collections or lease defaults.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	Only small portions of our revenues are dependent on contingent revenue sources.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P32_S1	Revenues from fixed rents and operating expense reimbursements accounted for approximately 90% of our total revenues in 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P32_S2	Revenues from contingent sources, such as percentage rents, vending income and miscellaneous income, accounted for approximately 10% of our total revenues in 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	Stanley K. Tanger, the Company's founder, entered the outlet center busi ness in 1981.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	Prior to founding our company, Stanley K. Tanger and his son, Steven B. Tanger, our President and Chief Executive Officer, built and managed a successful family owned apparel manufacturing business, Tanger/Creighton, Inc., which included the operation of five outlet stores.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P34_S1	Based on their knowledge of the apparel and retail industries, as well as their experience operating Tanger/Creighton, Inc.'s outlet stores, they recognized that there would be a demand for outlet centers where a number of manufacturers could operate in a single location and attract a large number of shoppers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	Steven B. Tanger joined the Company in 1986, and by June 1993, the Tangers had developed 17 centers totaling approximately 1.5 million square feet.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P35_S1	In June 1993, we completed our i nitial public offering, making Tanger Factory Outlet Centers, Inc.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P35_S2	the first publicly traded outlet center company.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P35_S3	Since our initial public offering, we have grown our portfolio through the strategic development, expansion and acquisition of outlet centers and are now one of the largest owner operators of outlet centers in the country.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	Our company has been built on a firm foundation of strong and enduring business relationships coupled with conservative business practices.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P36_S1	We part ner with many of the world's best known and most respected retailers and manufacturers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P36_S2	By fostering and maintaining strong tenant relationships with these successful, high volume companies, we have been able to solidify our position as a leader in the outlet industry for well over a quarter century.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P36_S3	The confidence and trust that we have developed with our retail partners from the very beginning has allowed us to forge the impressive retail alliances that we enjoy today with approximately 360 brand name manufacturers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	Nothing takes the place of experience.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P37_S1	We have had a solid track record of success in the outlet industry for the past 30 years.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	In 1993, Tanger led the way by becoming the industry's first outlet center company to be publicly traded.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	Our seasoned team of real estate professionals utilize the knowledge and experience that we have gained to give us a competitive advantage and a history of accomplishments in the manufacturers' outlet business.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	We are proud to report that as of December 31, 2010, our wholly- owned outlet centers were 98% occupied with average tenant sales of $354 per square foot.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P40_S1	Our portfolio of properties has had an average occupancy rate of 95% or greater on December 31st of each year since 1981.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P40_S2	We believe our ability to achieve this level of performance is a testament to our long-standing tenant relationships, industry experience and our expertise in the development and operation of manufacturers' outlet centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	Growth does not happen by chance.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P41_S1	Our goal is to build shareholder value through a comprehensive, conservative plan for sustained, long-term growth.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P41_S2	We focus our efforts on increasing rents in our existing centers, renovating and expanding our mature centers and reaching new markets through ground-up developments or acquisitions of new outlet centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	Our leasing team implements an ongoing strategy designed to positively impact our bottom line.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P42_S1	This is accomplished through the aggressive marketing of available space to maintain our standard for high occupancy levels.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	Leases are negotiated to provide for inflation-based contractual rent increases or periodic fixed contractual rent increases and percentage rents.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P43_S1	Due to the overall high performance of our shopping centers, we have historically been able to renew leases at higher base rents per square-foot and attract stronger, more popular brands to replace underperforming tenants.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	We believe that there continue to be opportunities to introduce the Tanger brand in untapped or under-served markets across the United States and Canada in the long-term.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P44_S1	As we search across North America looking for new markets, we do our homework and determine site viability on a timely and cost-effective basis.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P44_S2	Our 30 years of outlet industry experience, extensive development expertise and strong retail relationships give us a distinct competitive advantage.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P44_S3	We expect development to continue to be important to the growth of our portfolio in the long-term.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	We follow a general set of guidelines when evaluating opportunities for the development of new centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P45_S1	This typically includes seeking locations within markets that have at least 1 million people residing within a 30 to 40 mile radius with an average household income of at least $65,000 per year, frontage on a major interstate or roadway that has excellent visibility and a traffic count of at least 55,000 cars per day.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P45_S2	Leading tourist, vacation and resort markets that receive a t least 5 million visitors annually are also closely evaluated.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P45_S3	Although our current goal is to target sites that are large enough to support centers with approximately 90 stores totaling at least 350,000 square feet, we maintain the flexibility to vary our minimum requirements based on the unique characteristics of a site, tenant demand and our prospects for future growth and success.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	In order to help ensure the viability of proceeding with a project, we gauge the interest of our retail partners first.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P46_S1	Historically, we required that at least 50% of the space in each center is pre-leased prior to acquiring the site and beginning construction.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P46_S2	This pre-leasing policy is consistent with our conservative financing perspective and the discipline we impose upon ourselves.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	Co nstruction of a new outlet center has typically taken us nine to twelve months from groundbreaking to the opening of the first tenant stores.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	Keeping our shopping centers vibrant and growing is a key part of our formula for success.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P48_S1	In order to maintain our reputation as the premiere outlet shopping destination in the markets that we serve, we have an ongoing program of renovations and expansions taking place at our outlet centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P48_S2	Construction for expansion and renovation to existing properties typically takes less time, usually between six to nine months depending on the scope of the project.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	As a means of creating a presence in key markets and to create shareholder value, we may selectively choose to acquire individual properties or portfolios of properties that meet our strategic investment criteria.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P49_S1	We believe that our extensive experience in the outlet center business, access to capital markets, familiarity with real estate markets and our management experience will allow us to evaluate and execute our acquisition strategy successfully over time.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P49_S2	Through our tenant relationships, our leasing professionals have the ability to implement a remerchandising strategy when needed to increase occupancy rates and value.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P49_S3	We believe that our managerial skills, marketi ng expertise and overall outlet industry experience will also allow us to add long-term value and viability to these centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	Increasing cash flow to enhance the value of our properties and operations remains a primary business objective.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	Through targeted marketing and operational efficiencies, we strive to improve sales and profitability of our tenants and our outlet centers as a whole.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P50_S2	Achieving higher base and percentage rents and generating additional income from temporary le asing, vending and other sources also remains an important focus and goal.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	The long-standing retailer relationships that we enjoy allow us the ability to provide our sho ppers with a collection of the world's most popular outlet stores.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	Tanger customers shop and save on their favorite brand name merchandise including men's, women's and children's ready-to-wear, lifestyle apparel, footwear, jewelry accessories, tableware, housewares, luggage and domestic goods.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	In order for our centers to perform at a high level, our leasing professionals continually monitor and evaluate tenant mix, store size, store location and sales performance.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P53_S1	They also work to assist our tenants through re-sizing and re-location of retail space within each of our centers for maximum sales of each retail unit across our portfolio.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	Our marketing plans deliver compelling, well-crafted messages and enticing promotions and events to targeted audiences for tangible, meaningful and measurable results.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P54_S1	Our plans are based on a basic measure of success - increase sales and traffic for our retail partners and we will create successful centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P54_S2	Utilizing a strategic mix of print, radio, television, direct mail, website, internet advertising, social networks, smart phone applications and public relations, we consistently reinforce the message that Tanger is the place to shop for the best brands and the biggest outlet savings - direct from the manufacturer .
1004036_11_ITEM1_P54_S3	Our marketing efforts are also designed to build loyalty with current Tanger shoppers and create awareness with potential customers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P54_S4	The majority of consumer-marketing expenses incurred by us are reimbursable by our tenants.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	We believe we achieve a strong and flexible financial position by attempting to: (1) maintain a conservative leverage position relative to our portfolio when pursuing new development, expansion and acquisition opportunities, (2) extend and sequence our debt maturities, (3) manage our interest rate risk through a proper mix of fixed and variable rate debt, (4) maintain access to liquidity by using our lines of credit in a conservative manner and (5) preserve internally generated sources of capital by s trategically divesting of our underperforming assets and maintaining a conservative distribution payout ratio.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	We intend to retain the ability to raise additional capital, including public debt or equity, to pursue attractive investment opportunities that may arise and to otherwise act in a manner that we believe to be in the best interests of our shareholders and unit holders.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	The Company is a well-known seasoned issuer with a shelf registration that allows us to register unspecified amounts of different classes of securities on Form S-3.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P58_S0	To generate capital to reinvest into other attractive investment opportunities, we may also consider the use of additional operational and developmental joint ventures, the sale or lease of outparcel s on our existing properties and the sale of certain properties that do not meet our long-term investment criteria.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P58_S1	Based on cash provided by operations, existing lines of credit, ongoing negotiations with certain financial institutions and our ability to sell debt or issue equity subject to market conditions, we believe that we have access to the necessary financing to fund the planned capital expenditures during 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P59_S0	We anticipate that adequate cash will be available to fund our operating and administrative expenses, regular debt service obligations, and the payment of dividends in accordance with REIT requirements in both the short and long-term.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P59_S1	Although we receive most of our rental payments on a monthly basis , distributions to shareholders and unitholders are made quarterly and interest payments on the senior, unsecured notes are made semi-annually.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P59_S2	Amounts accumulated for such payments will be used in the interim to reduce the outstanding borrowings under our existing lines of credit or invested in short-term money market or other suitable instruments adhering to our investment policies.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P60_S0	We believe our current balance sheet position is financially sound; however, due to the uncertainty and unpredictability of the capital and credit markets, we can give no assurance that affordable access to capital will exist between now and 2013 when our next significant debt maturities occur.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P60_S1	As a result, our current primary focus is to strengthen our capital and liquidity position by controlling and reducing construction and overhead costs, generating positive cash flows from operations to cover our distributions and reducing outstanding debt.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P61_S0	We carefully consider the degree of existing and planned competition in a proposed area before deciding to develop, acquire or expand a new center.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P61_S1	Our centers compete for customers primarily with outlet centers built and operated by different developers, traditional shopping malls and full- and off-price retailers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P61_S2	However, we believe that the majority of our customers visit outlet centers because they are intent on buying name-brand products at discounted prices.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P61_S3	Traditional full- and off-price retailers are often unable to provide such a variety of name-brand products at attractive prices.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P62_S0	Tenants of outlet centers typically avoid direct competition with major retailers and their own specialty stores, and, therefore, generally insist that the outlet cente rs be located not less than 10 miles from the nearest major department store or the tenants' own specialty stores.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P62_S1	For this reason, our centers compete only to a very limited extent with traditional malls in or near metropolitan areas.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P63_S0	We compete directly with one large national owner of outlet centers and numerous small owners, however, there is the potential for increased competition from other developers who have announced plans to enter the outlet industry.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P63_S1	We believe the high barriers to entry in the outlet industry, including the need for extensive relationships with premier brand name manufacturers, have minimized the number of new outlet centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P64_S0	We rent space in an office building in Greensboro, North Carolina in which our corporate headquarters is located.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P64_S1	In addition, we rent a regional office in New York City, New York under a lease agreement and sublease agreement to better service our principal fashion-related tenants, many of whom are based in and around that area.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P65_S0	We mainta in offices and employ on-site managers at 32 centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P65_S1	The managers closely monitor the operation, marketing and local relationships at each of their centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P66_S0	We believe that as a whole our properties are covered by adequate comprehensive liability, fire, flood, earthquake and extended loss insurance provided by reputable companies with commercially reasonable and customary deductibles and limits.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P67_S0	Northline Indemnity, LLC, ("Northline"), a wholly-owned captive insurance subsidiary of the Op erating Partnership, is responsible for losses up to certain levels for property damage (including wind damage from hurricanes) prior to third-party insurance coverage.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P68_S0	Specified types and amounts of insurance are required to be carried by each tenant under their lease agreement with us.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P68_S1	There are however, types of losses, like those resulting from wars or nuclear radiation, which may either be uninsurable or not economically insurable in some or all of our locations.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P68_S2	An uninsured loss could result in a loss to us of both our capital investment and anticipated profits from the affected property.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P69_S0	As of February 1, 2011, we had 197 full-time employees, located at our corporate headquarters in North Carolina, our regional office in New York and 32 business offices.
1004036_11_ITEM1_P69_S1	At that date, we also employed 235 part-time employees at various locations.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	We may be unable to develop new outlet centers or expand existing ou tlet centers successfully.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	We continue to develop new outlet centers and expand outlet centers as opportunities arise.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P1_S1	However, there are significant risks associated with our development activities in addition to those generally associated with the ownership and operation of established retail properties.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P1_S2	While we have policies in place designed to limit the risks associated with development, these policies do not mitigate all development risks associated with a project.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	late completion because of construction delays, delays in the receipt of zoning, occupancy and other approvals or other factors outside of our control.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Any or all of these factors may impede our development strategy and adversely affect our overall business.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	The economic performance and the market value of our outlet centers are dependent on risks associated with real property investments.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Real property investments are subject to vary ing degrees of risk.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The economic performance and values of real estate may be affected by many factors, including changes in the national, regional and local economic climate, inflation, unemployment rates, consumer confidence, local conditions such as an oversupply of space or a reduction in demand for real estate in the area, the attractiveness of the properties to tenants, competition from other available space, our ability to provide adequate maintenance and insurance and increased operating costs.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Real property investments are relatively illiquid.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Our outlet centers represent a substantial portion of our total consolidated assets.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	As a result, our ability to sell one or more of our outlet centers in response to any changes in economic or other conditions is limited.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P8_S2	If we want to sell an outlet center, there can be no assurance that we will be able to dispose of it in the desired time period or that the sales price will exceed the cost of our investment.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Properties may be subject to impairment charges which can adversely affect our financial results.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We periodically evaluate long-lived assets to determine if there has been any impairment in their carrying values and record impairment losses if the undiscounted cash flows estimated to be generated by those assets are less than their carrying amounts or if there are other indicators of impairment.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	If it is determined that an impairment has occurred, we would be required to record an impairment charge equal to the excess of the asset's carrying value over its estimated fair value, which could have a material adverse effect on our financial results in the accounting period in which the adjustment is made.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Our estimates of undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated by each property are based on a number of assumptions that are subject to economic and market uncertainties including, but not limited to, demand for space, competition for tenants, changes in market rental rates and costs to operate each property.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P11_S1	As these factors are difficult to predict and are subject to future events that may alter our assumptions, the future cash flows estimated in our impairment analysis may not be achieved.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	We face competition for the acquisition and development of outlet centers, and we may not be able to complete acquisitions or developments that we have identified.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	We intend to grow our business through acquisitions and developments.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P13_S1	We compete with institutional pension funds, private equity investors, other REITs, small owners of outlet centers, specialty stores and others who are engaged in the acquisition, development or ownership of outlet centers and stores.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P13_S2	These competitors may succeed in acquiring or developing outlet centers themselves.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P13_S3	Also, our potential acquisition targets may find our competitors to be more attractive acquirers because they may have greater marketing and financial resources, may be willing to pay more, or may have a more compatible operating philosophy.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P13_S4	In addition, the number of entities competing to acquire or develop outlet centers may increase in the future, which would increase demand for these outlet centers and the prices we must pay to acquire or develop them.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P13_S5	If we pay higher prices for outlet centers, our profitability may be reduced.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P13_S6	Also, once we have identified potential acquisitions, such acquisitions are subject to the successful completion of due diligence, the negotiation of definitive agreements and the satisfaction of customary closing conditions.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P13_S7	We cannot assure you that we will be able to reach acceptable terms with the sellers or that these conditions will be satisfied.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	We may be subject to environmental regulation.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Under various federal, state and local laws, ordinances and regulations, we may be considered an owner or operator of real property and may be responsible for paying for the disposal or treatment of hazardous or toxic substances released on or in our property or disposed of by us, as well as certain other potential costs which could relate to hazardous or toxic substances (including governmental fines and injuries to persons and property).
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P15_S1	This liability may be imposed whether or not we knew about, or were responsible for, the presence of hazardous or toxic substances.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Our earnings and therefore our profitability are entirely dependent on rental income from real property.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Substantially all of our income is derived from rental income from real property.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P17_S1	Our income and funds for distribution would be adversely affected if a significant number of our tenants were unable to meet their obligations to us or if we were unable to lease a significant amount of space in our centers on economically favorable lease terms.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P17_S2	In addition, the terms of outlet store tenant leases traditionally have been significantly shorter than in other retail segments.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P17_S3	There can be no assurance that any tenant whose lease expires in the future will renew such lease or that we will be able to re-lease space o n economically favorable terms.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	We are substantially dependent on the results of operations of our retailers.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Our operations are subject to the results of operations of our retail tenants.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P19_S1	A portion of our rental revenues are derived from percentage rents that directly depend on the sales volume of certain tenants.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P19_S2	Accordingly, declines in these tenants' results of operations would reduce the income produced by our properties.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P19_S3	If the sales of our retail tenants decline sufficiently, such tenants may be unable to pay their existing rents as such rents would represent a higher percentage of their sales.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P19_S4	Any resulting leasing delays, failures to make payments or tenant bankruptcies could result in the termination of such tenants' leases.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	A number of companies in the retail industry, including some of our tenants, have declared bankruptcy or have voluntarily closed certain of their stores in recent years.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P20_S1	The bankruptcy of a major tenant or number of tenants may result in the closing of certain affected stores, and we may not be able to re-lease the resulting vacant sp ace for some time or for equal or greater rent.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Such bankruptcy could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and could result in a lower level of funds for distribution.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Certain of our properties are subject to ownership interests held by third parties, whose interests may conflict with ours and thereby constrain us from taking actions concerning these properties which otherwise would be in our best interests and our shareholders interests.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We own partial interests in and manage two outlet centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P22_S1	We perform the property management and leasing services for these properties and receive fees for these services.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	As property manager of the joint ventures that own the properties, we have certain fiduciary responsibilities to the other members in those joint ventures.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P23_S1	The approval or consent of the other members is required before we may sell, finance, expand or make other significant changes in the operations of such properties.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P23_S2	We also may not have control over certain major decisions, including leasing and the timing and amount of distributions, which could result in decisions by the managing member that do not fully reflect our interests.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P23_S3	To the extent such approvals or consents are required, we may experience difficulty in, or may be prevented from, implementing our plans with respect to expansion, development, financing or other similar transactions with respect to such properties.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	An uninsured loss or a loss that exceeds our insurance policies on our outlet centers or the insurance policies of our tenants could subject us to lost capital and revenue on those centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Some of the risks to which our outlet centers are subject, including risks of war and earthquakes, hurricanes and other natural disasters, are not insurable or may not be insurable in the future.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Should a loss occur that is uninsured or in an amount exceeding the combined aggregate limits for the insurance policies noted above or in the event of a loss that is subject to a substantial deductible under an insurance policy, we could lose all or part of our capital invested in and anticipated revenue from one or more of our outlet centers, which could adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition, as well as our ability to make distributions to our shareholders.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Under the terms and conditions of our leases, tenants generally are required to indemnify and hold us harmless from liabilities resulting from injury to persons and contamination of air, water, land or property, on or off the premises, due to activities conducted in the leased space, except for claims arising from negligence or intentional misconduct by us or our agents.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P26_S1	Additionally, tenants generally are required, at the tenant's expense, to obtain and keep in full force during the term of the lease, liability and property damage insurance policies issued by companies acceptable to us.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P26_S2	These policies include liability coverage for bodily injury and property damage arising out of the ownership, use, occupancy or maintenance of the leased space.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P26_S3	All of these policies may involve substantial deductibles and certain exclusions.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P26_S4	Therefore, an uninsured loss or loss that exceeds the insurance policies of our tenants could also subject us to lost capital and revenue.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Historically high fuel prices may impact consumer travel and spending habits.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Most shoppers use private automobile transportation to travel to our outlet centers and many of our centers are not easily accessible by public transportation.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P28_S1	Increasing fuel costs may reduce the number of trips to our centers thus reducing the amount spent at our centers.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Many of our outlet center locations near tourist destinations may experience an even more acute reduction of shoppers if there were a reduction of people opting to drive to vacation destinatio ns.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P28_S3	Such reductions in traffic could adversely impact our percentage rents and ability to renew and release space at current rental rates.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Increasing fuel costs may also reduce disposable income and decrease demand for retail products.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Such a decrease could adversely affect the results of operations of our retail tenants and adversely impact our percentage rents and ability to renew and release space at current rental rates.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	We are subject to the risks associated with debt financing.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We are subject to the risks associated with debt financing, including the risk that the cash provided by our operating activities will be insufficient to meet required payments of principal and interest.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P31_S1	Disruptions in the capital and credit markets may adversely affect our operations, including the ability to fund the planned capital expenditures and potential new developments or acquisitions.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P31_S2	Further, there is the risk that we will not be able to repay o r refinance existing indebtedness or that the terms of any refinancing will not be as favorable as the terms of existing indebtedness.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P31_S3	If we are unable to access capital markets to refinance our indebtedness on acceptable terms, we might be forced to dispose of properties on disadvantageous terms, which might result in losses.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P32_S0	The Company's failure to qualify as a REIT could subject our earnings to corporate level taxation.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We believe that we have operated and intend to operate in a manner that permits the Company to qualify as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P33_S1	However, we cannot assure you that the Company has qualified or will remain qualified as a REIT.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P33_S2	If in any taxable year the Company were to fail to qualify as a REIT and certain statutory relief provisions were not applicable, the Company would not be allowed a deduction for distributions to shareholders in computing taxable income and would be subject to U.S. federal income tax (including any applicable alternative minimum tax) on our taxable income at regular corporate rates.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P33_S3	The Company's failure to qualify for taxation as a REIT would have an adverse effect on the market price and marketability of our securitie s.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P34_S0	The Company is required by law to make distributions to our shareholders.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P35_S0	To obtain the favorable tax treatment associated with the Company's qualification as a REIT, generally, the Company is required to distribute to its shareholders at least 90.0% of its net taxable income (excluding capital gains) each year.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P35_S1	The Company depends upon distributions or other payments from the Operating Partnership to make distributions to the Company's common shareholders.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P35_S2	A recent IRS revenue procedure allows the Company to satisfy the R EIT income distribution requirement by distributing up to 90% of the dividends on its common shares in the form of additional common shares in lieu of paying dividends entirely in cash.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P35_S3	Although we reserve the right to utilize this procedure in the future, we currently have no intent to do so.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P36_S0	In the event that the Company pays a portion of a dividend in shares, taxable U.S. shareholders would be required to pay income tax on the entire amount of the dividend, including the portion paid in shares, in which case such shareholders might have to pay the income tax using cash from other sources.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P36_S1	If a U.S. shareholder sells the shares it receives as a dividend in order to pay this income tax, the sales proceeds may be less than the amount included in income with respect to the dividend, depending on the market price of our shares at the time of the sale.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P37_S0	The Company depends on distributions from the Operating Partnership to meet its financial obligations, including dividends.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P38_S0	The Company's operations are conducted by the Operating Partnership, and the Company's only significant asset is its interest in the Operating Partnership.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P38_S1	As a result, the Company depends upon distributions or other payments from the Operating Partnership in order to meet its financial obligations, including its obligations under any guarantees or to pay dividends or liquidation payments to its common shareholders.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P38_S2	As a result, these obligations are effectively subordinated to existing and future liabilities of the Operating Partnership.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P39_S0	The Operating Partnership is a party to loan agreements with various bank lenders that require the Operating Partnership to comply with various financial and other covenants before it may make distributions to the Company.
1004036_11_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Although the Operating Partnership presently is in compliance with these covenants, there is no assurance that the Operating Partnershi p will continue to be in compliance and that it will be able to make distributions to the Company.
1004036_11_ITEM1B_P0_S0	There are no unresolved staff comments from the Commission for either the Company or the Operating Partnership.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P0_S0	As of February 1, 2011, our wholly-owned portfolio consisted of 31 outlet centers totaling 9.2 million square feet located in 21 states.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P0_S1	We operate and own interests in two other centers totaling approximately 948,000 square feet through unconsolidated joint ventures.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P0_S2	Our centers range in size from 24,619 to 729,475 square feet.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P0_S3	The centers are generally located near tourist destinations or along major interstate highways to provide visibility and accessibility to potential customers.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P1_S0	We believe that the centers are well diversified geographically and by tenant and that we are not dependent upon any single property or tenant.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P1_S1	Our Riverhead, New York center is the only property that represented more than 10% of our consolidated total revenues for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P1_S2	No property represented more than 10% of our consolidated total assets as of December 31, 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P1_S3	See Properties - Significant Property for further details.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P2_S0	We have an ongoing strategy of acquiring centers, developing new centers and expanding existing centers.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P2_S1	See Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations--Liquidity and Capital Resources for a discussion of the cost of such programs and the sources o f financing thereof.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P3_S0	Of the 31 outlet centers in our wholly-owned portfolio, we own the land underlying 27 and have ground leases on four.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P3_S1	The following table sets forth information about the land leases on which all or a portion of the four centers are located:
1004036_11_ITEM2_P4_S0	(1) Lease may be renewed at our option for additional terms of twenty years each.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P5_S0	The initial term of our typical tenant lease averages approximately five years.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P5_S1	Generally, leases provide for the payment of fixed monthly rent in advance.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P5_S2	There are often contractual base rent increases during the initial term of the lease.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P5_S3	In addition, the rental payments are customarily subject to upward adjustments based upon tenant sales volume.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P5_S4	Most leases provide for payment by the tenant of real estate taxes, insurance, common area maintenance, advertising and promotion expenses incurred by the applicable center.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P5_S5	As a result, the majority of our operating expenses for the centers are borne by the tenants.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P6_S0	The following table summarizes certain information with respect to our wholly-owned outlet centers as of February 1, 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P7_S0	The following table summarizes certain information with respect to our existing outlet centers in which we have an ownership interest as of February 1, 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P7_S1	Except as noted, all properties are fee owned.

1004036_11_ITEM2_P8_S1	(2) Includes a 29,253 square foot warehouse adjacent to the property utilized to support the operations of the retail tenants.

1004036_11_ITEM2_P17_S0	Depreciation on the outlet centers is computed on the straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P17_S1	We generally use estimated lives ranging from 25 to 33 years for buildings, 15 years for land improvements and seven years for equipment.
1004036_11_ITEM2_P17_S2	Expenditures for ordinary maintenance and repairs are charged to operations as incurred while significant renovations and improvements, including tenant finishing allowances, which improve and/or extend the useful life of the asset are capitalized and depreciated over their estimated useful life.

1004036_11_ITEM2_P17_S5	Real estate taxes for 2011 are estimated to be approximately $4.0 million.

1004036_11_ITEM2_P20_S1	In our opinion, the ultimate resolution of these matters are not expected to have a material effect on our results of operations or financial condition.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P0_S0	EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF TANGER FACTORY OUTLET CENTERS, INC.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P1_S0	The following table sets forth certain information concerning the Company's executive officers.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P1_S1	The Operating Partnership does not have executive officers:
1004036_11_ITEM4_P2_S0	Director, President and Chief Executive Officer Frank C. Marchisello, Jr.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P3_S0	(1) In January 2011 Kevin M. Dillon announced his resignation from the Company effective in April 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P4_S0	The following is a biographical summary of the experience of our e xecutive officers:
1004036_11_ITEM4_P5_S0	Mr. Tanger is a director of the Company and was named President and Chief Executive Officer effective January 1, 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P5_S1	Mr. Tanger served as President and Chief Operating Officer from January 1, 1995 to December 2008.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P5_S2	Previously, Mr. Tanger served as Executive Vice President from 1986 to December 1994.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P5_S3	He has been with Tanger related companies for most of his professional career, having served as Executive Vice President of Tanger/Creighton for 10 years.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P5_S4	Mr. Tanger is a graduate of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the Stanford University School of Business Executive Program.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P6_S0	Mr. Marchisello was named Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer in April 2003 and was additionally named Secretary in May 2005.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P6_S1	Previously he was named Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer in January 1999 after being named Vice President and Chief Financial Officer in November 1994.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P6_S2	He served as Chief Accounting Officer from January 1993 to November 1994.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P6_S3	He was employed by Gilliam, Coble Moser, certified public accountants, from 1981 to 1992, the last six years of which he was a partner of the firm in charge of various real estate clients.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P6_S4	Mr. Marchisello is responsible for the Company's financial repor ting processes, as well as supervisory responsibility over the senior officers that oversee the Company's accounting, finance, corporate communications and information systems functions.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P6_S5	Mr. Marchisello is a graduate of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and is a certified public accountant.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P7_S0	Mr. McDonough was na med Executive Vice President of Operations in August 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P7_S1	Previously, he was the Co-Founder and Principal of MHF Real Estate Group, a real estate asset management firm, from September 2009 to August 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P7_S2	He served as Chief Investment Officer and was a member of the Investment Committee at Equity One, Inc. from July 2007 to April 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P7_S3	From April 2006 to July 2007, Mr. McDonough was a partner at Kahl Goveia, and from February 1997 to April 2006, he was employed by Regency Centers Corp., and its predecessor, Pacific Retail Trust, as the national director of acquisitions and dispositions.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P7_S4	Previously, from July 1984 to January 1997, Mr. McDonough served in various capacities, including partner and principal, with Trammell Crow Company.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P7_S5	Mr. McDonough has supervisory responsibility over the senior officers that oversee the Company's operations, construction and development, leasing and marketing functions.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P7_S6	Mr. McDonough is a graduate of Stanford University and holds an MBA degree from Harvard Business Scho ol.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P8_S0	Ms. Geldner was named Senior Vice President - Marketing in May 2000.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P8_S1	Previously, she held the position of Vice President - Marketing from September 1996 to May 2000 and Assistant Vice President - Marketing from December 1995 to September 1996.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P8_S2	Prior to joining Tanger, Ms. Geldner was with Prime Retail, L.P. for 4 years where she served as Regional Marketing Director responsible for coordinating and directing marketing for five outlet centers in the southeast region.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P8_S3	Previously, Ms. Geldner was Marketing Manager for North Hills, Inc. for five years and also served in the same role for the Edward J. DeBartolo Corp. for two years.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P8_S4	Her major responsibilities inclu de managing the Company's marketing department and developing and overseeing implementation of all corporate and field marketing programs.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P8_S5	Ms. Geldner is a graduate of East Carolina University.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P9_S0	Mr. Dillon was named Senior Vice President - Construction and Development in August 2004.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P9_S1	Previously, he held the positions of Vice President - Construction and Development from May 2002 to August 2004, Vice President - Construction from October 1997 to May 2002, Director of Construction from September 1996 to October 1997 and Construction Manager from November 1993, the month he joined the Company, to September 1996.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P9_S2	Prior to joining the Company, Mr. Dillon was employed by N ew Market Development Company for six years where he served as Senior Project Manager.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P9_S3	Prior to joining New Market, Mr. Dillon was the Development Director of Western Development Company where he spent 6 years.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P9_S4	His major responsibilities include oversite of site selection and predevelopment as well as management of all aspects of the Company's construction projects including new developments, renovations and expansions.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P10_S0	Mr. Dillon attended Northern Michigan University and George Washington University.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P10_S1	In January 2011, Mr. Dillon announced his resignation from the Company effective in April 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P11_S0	Ms. Morrison was named Senior Vice President - Leasing in August 200 4.
1004036_11_ITEM4_P11_S1	Previously, she held the positions of Vice President - Leasing from May 2001 to August 2004, Assistant Vice President of Leasing from August 2000 to May 2001 and Director of Leasing from April 1999 until August 2000.

1004036_11_ITEM5_P2_S0	As of February 1, 2011, there were approximately 512 common shareholders of record.
1004036_11_ITEM5_P3_S0	The Company operates in a manner intended to enable it to qualify as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code, or the Code.
1004036_11_ITEM5_P3_S1	A REIT is required to distribute at least 90% of its taxable income to its shareholders each year.
1004036_11_ITEM5_P3_S2	We intend to continue to qualify as a REIT and to distribute substantially all of our taxable income to our shareholders through the payment of regular quarterly dividends.
1004036_11_ITEM5_P3_S3	Certain of our debt agreements limit the payment of dividends such that dividends shall not exceed funds f rom operations (" FFO"), as defined in the agreements, for the prior fiscal year on an annual basis or 95% of FFO on a cumulative basis.
1004036_11_ITEM5_P4_S0	The information required by this Item is set forth in Part III Item 12 of this document.

1004036_11_ITEM5_P6_S0	The following share price performance chart compares our performance to the index of equity REITs prepared by the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts ("NAREIT"), and the SNL Shopping Center REIT index prepared by SNL Financial.
1004036_11_ITEM5_P7_S0	Equity REITs are defined as those that derive more than 75% of their income from equity investments in real estate assets.
1004036_11_ITEM5_P7_S1	The NAREIT equity index includes all tax qualified real estate investment trusts listed on the New York Stock Exchange, American Stock Exchange or the NASDAQ National Market System.
1004036_11_ITEM5_P8_S0	All share price performance assumes an initial investment of $100 at the beginning of the period and assumes the reinvestment of dividends.

1004036_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	BASE RENTALS Base rentals increased $ 4.9 million , or 3%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in various components of base rents from 2009 to 2010 (in thousands):
1004036_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	Base rental income generated from existing properties in our portfolio increased due to increases in rental rates on lease renewals and incremental rents from re-tenanting vacant space.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	In November 2010, we opened our new outlet center in Mebane, North Carolina and during the second quarter of 2009 opened an additional expansion phase at our Commerce II, Georgia outlet center.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	During the second quarter of 2010, we completed the demolition of approximately 162,000 square feet at our center in Hilton Head, South Carolina.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	The redevelopment of this site began during the second quarter of 2010 with the opening of a new 176,000 square foot outlet center expected in the second quarter of 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	Also, included in base rentals is the amortization from the value of the above and below market leases recorded as a result of our property acquisitions as either an increase (in the case of below market leases) or a decrease (in the case of above market leases) to rental income over the remaining term of the associated lease.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P9_S1	At December 31, 2010 , the net liability representing the amount of unrecognized combined above and below market lease values totaled approximately $1.5 million.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P9_S2	If a tenant vacates its space prior to the contractual termination of the lease and no rental payments are being made on the lease, any unamortized balance of the related above or below market lease value will be written off and could materially impact our net income positively or negatively.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	PERCENTAGE RENTALS Percentage rentals, which represent revenues based on a percentage of tenants' sales volume above predetermined levels (the "breakpoint"), increased $1.1 million, or 16% from the 2009 period to the 2010 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	The increase in percentage rentals are directly related to the strength of our tenants' sales.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P10_S2	Reported tenant comparable sales for our wholly owned properties for the year ended December 31, 2010 increased 6.6% to $354 per square foot.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P10_S3	Reported tenant comparable sales is defined as the weighted average sales per square foot reported in space open for the full duration of each comparison period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENTS Expense reimbursements increased $2.1 million , or 3%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in various components of expense reimbursements from 2009 to 2010 (in thousands):
1004036_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	Expense reimbursements, which represent the contractual recovery from tenants of certain common area maintenance, insurance, property tax, promotional, advertising and management expenses, generally fluctuate consistently with the reimb ursable property operating expenses to which they relate.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	OTHER INCOME Other income decreased $2.5 million, or 22%, in the 2010 period as compared to the 2009 period due primarily to the $3.3 million gain on the sale of a land outparcel at our Washington, PA center in August 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P13_S1	This decrease was partially offset by the incremental other income generated from the opening of the center in Mebane, NC in November 2010 and an increase in Tanger Club memberships and other vending categories.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	PROPERTY OPERATING EXPENSES Property operating expenses increased $5.2 million, or 6%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	The follow ing table sets forth the changes in various components of property operating expenses from 2009 to 2010 thousands):
1004036_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	The increase in existing property operating expenses is primarily due to increases in snow removal in 2010 due to extreme winter weather in December in the eastern portion of the United States and normal annual increases associated with operating mall offices throughout our portfolio.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES General and administrative expenses decreased $8.0 million, or 25%, in th e 2010 period as compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	Effective September 1, 2009, Stanley K. Tanger, founder of the Company, retired as an employee of the Company.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P17_S1	His severance, totaling $10.3 million, consisted of a cash payment of $3.4 million and $6.9 million of share-based compensation from the accelerated vesting of restricted common shares.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P17_S2	Excluding this severance, general and administrative expenses increased $2.3 million primarily as a result of additional share-based compensation expense related to the 2010 notional unit plan and increases in other professional and legal fees.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	DEPRECIATION AND AMORTIZATION EXPENSES Depreciation and amortization decreased $1.9 million, or 2%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P18_S1	The majority of the decrease is due to lower levels of intangible lease cost amortization from acquired outlet centers in 2003, 2005 and 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P18_S2	These decreases were partially offset by additional depreciation and amortization of approximately $9.0 million and $6.3 million recognized during the 2010 and 2009 period s, respectively, related to the demolition and redevelopment plan at our Hilton Head I, SC center.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P19_S0	IMPAIRMENT CHARGE In 2005 we sold our outlet center located in Seymour, Indiana, but retained various outparcels of land at the development site, some of which we had sold in recent years.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P19_S1	In February 2010, our Board of Directors approved the sale of the remaining parcels of land in Seymour, IN.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P19_S2	As a result of this Board approval and an approved plan to actively market the land for sale, we accounted for the land as "held for sale" and recorded a non-cash impairment charge of approximately $735,000 in our consolidated statements of operations which equaled the excess of the carrying amount of the land over its fair value at that time.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P19_S3	We determined the estimated fair value using a market approach considering offers that we had obtained for all the various parcels less estimated closing costs.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P20_S0	INTEREST EXPENSE Interest expense decreased $3.6 million, or 9%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P20_S1	This decrease was due to the significant reduction in the average amount of debt outstanding through an exchange offering in May 2009 and a common share offering in August 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P20_S2	These two equity transactions in essence retired approximately $259.1 million of outstanding debt.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P21_S0	The 2010 period includes the write-off of approximately $563,000 of unamortized loan origination costs.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P21_S1	These assets were written-off due to the repayment of the $235.0 million term loan facility in the 2010 period with a portion of the proceeds from the 2020 Notes.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P21_S2	In May 2009, senior exchangeable notes of the Operating Partnership in the principal amount of $142.3 million and a carrying amount of $135.3 million were exchanged for common shares of the Company, representing approximately 95.2% of the total senior exchangeable notes outstanding prior to the exchange offer.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P21_S3	In the aggregate, the exchange offer resulted in the issuance of approximately 9.7 million common shares and the payment of approximately $1.2 million in cash for accrued and unpaid interest and in lieu of fractional shares.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P21_S4	Following settlement of the exchange offer, senior exchangeable notes in the principal amount of approximately $7.2 million remained outstanding.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P21_S5	In connection with the exchange offering, we recognized in income from continuing operations and net income a gain on early extinguishment of debt in the amount of $10.5 million.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	LOSS ON TERMINATION OF DERIVATIVES During the second quarter of 2010, we terminated two interest rate swap agreements with a total notional amount of $235.0 million.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P22_S1	These agreements were originally entered into in 2008 for the purpose of fixing the LIBOR based interest rate on the $235.0 million term loan facility originally completed in June 2008.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P22_S2	We paid approximately $6.1 million to terminate the two interest rate swap agreements.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P22_S3	The agreements were terminated because the underlying debt for the derivative transaction was repaid with a portion of the proceeds from the 2020 Notes.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	Prior to when they were terminated, the swaps were designated as cash flow hedges.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P23_S1	Unrealized gains and losses related to the effective portion of the swaps were recognized in other comprehensive income.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P23_S2	Because the swaps were highly effective, the amount included in accumulated other comprehensive income when the swaps were terminated was equal to the amount recorded as a liability on the balance sheet.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P23_S3	The contemporaneous termination of the swaps and the related debt caused the amounts in accumulated other comprehensive income to be reclassified to earnings.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P23_S4	Additionally, a payment of $6.1 million, which was considered to be an investing activity in the statement of cash flows, was made to relieve the obligation that was recorded as a liability.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	GAIN ON FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENT OF PREVIOUSLY HELD INTEREST IN ACQUIRED JOINT VENTURE On January 5, 2009, we purchased the remaining 50% interest in the Myrtle Beach Hwy 17 joint venture for a cash price of $32.0 million and the assumption of the existing mortgage loan of $35.8 million.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P24_S1	The acquisition was funded by amounts available under our unsecured lines of credit.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P24_S2	We had owned a 50% interest in the Myrtle Beach Hwy 17 joint venture since its formation in 2001 and accounted for it under the equity method.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P24_S3	The joint venture is now 100% owned by us and has been consolidated since January 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P24_S4	The acquis ition was accounted for under the new guidance for acquisitions which was effective January 1, 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P24_S5	Under this guidance, we recorded a gain of $31.5 million which represented the difference between the fair market value of our previously owned interest and its cost basis.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	EQUITY IN EARNINGS (LOSSES) OF UNCONSOLIDATED JOINT VENTURES Equity in earnings (losses) of unconsolidated joint ventures increased by $1.0 million, or 69%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P25_S1	The improvement is due to the natural expiration of $170.0 million of interest rate swaps at the Deer Park joint venture in June 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P25_S2	The expiration of these swaps enabled the joint venture to incur interest at a variable rate based on a LIBOR index that is currently at historically low levels.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P25_S3	The increase was offset slightly by higher interest rate levels at our Wisconsin Dells joint venture which refinanced its $24.8 million mortgage loan in December 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P25_S4	The new mortgage included a credit spread over the LIBOR rate of 3.00% compared to a credit spread of 1.30% in the expiring mortgage.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS In May 2010, the Company's Board of Directors approved a plan for our management to sell our Commerce I, Geo rgia center.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P26_S1	The facts and circumstances of the plan met the accounting requirements to classify the results of operations of the center as discontinued operations.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P26_S2	The majority of the center was sold in July 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P26_S3	The remaining portion of the center was sold during the first quarter of 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P26_S4	During the third quarter of 2010, we recorded an impairment of approximately $111,000 to lower the basis of the remaining portion of the center to its approximate fair value based on the actual sales contracts related to the center.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P26_S5	In the 2009 period, we recorded an impairment charge for the Commerce I, GA property of $5.2 million which equaled the excess of the property's carrying value over its estimated fair value at that time.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	BASE RENTALS Base rentals increased $16.3 million, or 10%, in the 2009 period compared to the 2008 period.

1004036_11_ITEM7_P28_S2	The Myrtle Beach Hwy 17 outlet center is now wholly-owned and has been consolidated in our 2009 period results.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P29_S0	Base rental income generated from existing properties in our portfolio increased due to increases in rental rates on lease renewals and incremental rents from re-tenanting vacant space.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P30_S0	The above increases were partially offset by a reduction at existing centers in the recognition of termination fees in the 2009 period compared to the 2008 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P30_S1	The 2009 period included approximately $1.0 million of termination fees compared to $1.5 million in the 2008 period due to fewer tenants terminating leases early.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P30_S2	Payments received from the early termination of leases are recognized as revenue from the time the payment is receivable until the tenant vacates the space.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P31_S0	Also, included in base rentals is the amortization from the value of the above and below market leases recorded as a result of our property acquisitions as either an increase (in the case of below market leases) or a decrease (in the case of above market leases) to rental income over the remaining term of the associated lease.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P31_S1	The net amortization of above and below market leases, excluding the newly acquired Myrtle Beach Hwy 17 property, for the 2009 period was an increase to base rentals of approximately $70,000.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P31_S2	This represents a decrease of approximately $286,000, or 80%, over the 2008 period amount of approximately $356,000.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P31_S3	The decrease is due to the aging acquired leases that exist in our portfolio.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P32_S0	At December 31, 2009, the net liability representing the amount of unrecognized combined above and below market lease values totaled approximately $2.4 million.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P32_S1	If a tenant vacates its space prior to the contractual termination of the lease and no rental payments are being made on the lease, any unamortized balance of the related above or below market lease value will be written off and could materially impact our net income positively or negatively.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P33_S0	PERCENTAGE RENTALS Percentage rentals, which represent revenues based on a percentage of tenants' sales volu me above predetermined levels (the "breakpoint"), decreased $257,000, or 4% from the 2008 period to the 2009 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P33_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in percentage rentals from 2008 to 2009 (in thousands):
1004036_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	The decrease in percentage rentals are directly related to the strength of our tenants' sales.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P35_S0	Tenant sales were negatively impacted by the general weakness in the US economy.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P35_S1	In addition, a significant number of tenants that renewed t heir leases renewed at much higher base rental rates and, accordingly, had increases to their contractual breakpoint levels used in determining their percentage rentals.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P35_S2	This essentially transformed a variable rent component into a fixed rent component.

1004036_11_ITEM7_P42_S0	GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES General and administrative expenses increased $10.3 million, or 46%, in the 2009 period as compared to the 2008 period.
1004036_11_ITEM7_P43_S0	Effective September 1, 2009, Stanley K. Tanger, founder of the Company, retired as an employee of the Company.
