1004036_11_ITEM15_P70_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P71_S0	Tanger Factory Outlet Centers, Inc. and subsidiaries is one of the largest owners and operators of outlet centers in the United States.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P71_S1	We are a fully-integrated, self-administered and self-managed real estate investment trust ("REIT") which, through our controlling interest in the Operating Partnership, focuses exclusively on developing, acquiring, owning, operating and managing outlet shopping centers.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P71_S2	As of December 31, 2010 , we owned and operated 31 outlet centers, with a total gross leasable area of approximately 9.2 million square feet.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P71_S3	All references to gross leasable area, square feet, occupancy, stores and store brands contained in the notes to the consolidated financial statements are unaudited.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P72_S0	These outlet centers were 98% occupied and contained over 2,000 stores, representing approximately 360 store brands.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P72_S1	Also, we operated and had partial ownership interests in two outlet centers totaling approximately 948,000 square feet.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P73_S0	Our outlet centers and other assets are held by, and all of our operations are conducted by, Tanger Properties Limited Partnership and subsidiaries.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P73_S1	Accordingly, the descriptions of our business, employees and properties are also descriptions of the business, employees and properties of the Operating Partnership.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P73_S2	Unless the context indicates otherwise, the term Company refers to Tanger Factory Outlet Centers, Inc. and subsidiaries and the term Operating Partnership refers to Tanger Properties Limited Partnership and subsidiaries.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P73_S3	The terms we , our and us refer to the Company or the Company and the Operating Partnership together, as the text requires.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P74_S0	We own the majority of the units of partnership interest issued by the Operating Partnership through our two wholly-owned subsidiaries, the Tanger GP Trust and the Tanger LP Trust.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P74_S1	The Tanger GP Trust controls the Operating Partnership as its sole general partner.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P74_S2	The Tanger LP Trust holds a limited partnership interest.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P74_S3	The Tanger family, through its ownership of the Tanger Family Limited Partnership holds the remaining units as a limited partner.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P75_S0	As of December 31, 2010 , our wholly-owned subsidiaries owned 20,249,017 units of the Operating Partnership and the Tanger Family Limited Partnership owned the remaining 3,033,305 units.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P75_S1	Each Tanger Family Limited Partnership unit is exchangeable for four of our common shares, subject to certain limitations to preserve our status as a REIT.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P76_S0	Principles of Consolidation - The consolidated financial statements of the Company include its accounts and its wholly-owned subsidiaries, as well as the Operating Partnership and its subsidiaries.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P76_S1	The consolidated financial statements of the Operating Partnership include its accounts and its wholly-owned subsidiaries.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P76_S2	Intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P77_S0	Investments in real estate joint ventures that represent non-controlling ownership interests are accounted for using the equity method of accounting.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P78_S0	In accordance with amended guidance related to the consolidation of variable interest entities which became effective January 1, 2010, we performed an analysis of all of our real estate joint ventures to determine whether they would qualify as variable interest entities ("VIE"), and whether the joint venture should be consolidated or accounted for as an equity method investment in an unconsolidated joint venture.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P78_S1	As a result of our qualitative assessment, we concluded that Deer Park is a VIE and Wisconsin Dells is not a VIE.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P78_S2	Deer Park is considered a VIE because it does not meet the criteria of the members having a sufficient equity investment at risk.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P79_S0	After making the determination that Deer Park was a VIE, we performed an assessment to determine if we would be considered the primary beneficiary and thus be required to consolidate Deer Park's balance sheets and results of operations.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P79_S1	This assessment was based upon whether we had the following:
1004036_11_ITEM15_P80_S0	Based on the provisions of the operating and management agreements of Deer Park, we determined that no one member alone has the power to direct the significant activities that affect the economic performance of Deer Park.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P81_S0	We have determined that all three partners share power in the decisions that most significantly impact Deer Park, as well as the financial rights and obligations, and therefore we are not required to consolidate Deer Park.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P81_S1	Our equity method investment in Deer Park as of December 31, 2010 was approximately $1.6 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P81_S2	We are unable to estimate our maximum exposure to loss at this time because our guarantees are limited and based on the future operating performance of Deer Park.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P81_S3	Our maximum exposure consists of the following components: our investment, our completion guarantee which is currently estimated to be up to $15.0 million and our other operating performance guarantees.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P82_S0	Share Split - The Company's Board of Directors declared a 2 for 1 split of the Company's common shares on January 13, 2011, effected in the form of a share dividend, payable on January 24, 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P82_S1	The Company retained the current par value of $.01 per share for all common shares.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P82_S2	All references to the number of shares outstanding, per share amounts and share option data of the Company's common shares have been restated to reflect t he effect of the split for all periods presented.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P82_S3	Shareholders' equity reflects the split by reclassifying from additional paid in capital to common shares an amount equal to the par value of the additional shares arising from the split.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P82_S4	While the number of Operating Partnership units did not change as a result of the split, each Tanger Family Limited Partnership unit is now exchangeable for four of the Company's common shares.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P82_S5	Previously, the exchange ratio was one unit for two common shares.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P83_S0	Noncontrolling interests - In the Company's consolidated financial statements, the Noncontrolling interest in Operating Partnership reflects the Tanger Family Limited Partnership's percentage ownership of the Operating Partnership's units.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P83_S1	Income is allocated to the Tanger Family Limited Partnership based on its respective ownership interest.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P84_S0	Related Parties - The Tanger Family Limited Partnership, see Noncontrolling interests , is a related party which holds a limited partnership interest in the Operating Partnership and is reflected in the Company's consolidated financial statements as the noncontrolling interest in the Operating Partnership.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P84_S1	See Note 24 for further discussion of the relationship and transactions between the Tanger Family Limited Partnership and the Company and Operating Partnership.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P85_S0	The nature of our relationships and the related party transactions for our unconsolidated joint ventures are also discussed in Note 4.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P86_S0	Use of Estimates - The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumption s that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P86_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P87_S0	Operating Segments - We aggregate the financial information of all outlet centers into one reportable operating segment because the centers all have similar economic characteristics and provide similar products and services to similar types and classes of customers.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P88_S0	Rental Property - Rental properties are recorded at cost less accumulated depreciation.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P88_S1	Costs incurred for the construction and development of properties, including certain general and overhead costs, are capitalized.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P88_S2	The amount of general and overhead costs capitalized is based on our estimate of the amount of costs directly related to the construction or development of these assets.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P88_S3	Direct costs to acquire existing centers are expensed as incurred.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P89_S0	Depreciation is computed on the straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P89_S1	We generally use estimated lives ranging from 25 to 33 years for buildings and improvements, 15 years for land improvements and seven years for equipment.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P89_S2	Expenditures for ordinary maintenance and repairs are charged to operations as incurred while significant renovations and improvements, including tenant finishing allowances, which improve and/or extend the useful life of the asset are capitalized and depreciated over their estimated useful life.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P89_S3	Interest costs are capitalized during periods of active construction for qualified expenditures based upon interest rates in place during the construction period until construction is substantially complete.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P89_S4	Capitalized interest costs are amortized over lives which are consistent with the constructed assets.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P90_S0	In accordance with accounting guidance for business combinations, we allocate the purchase price of acquisitions based on the fair value of land, building, tenant improvements, debt and deferred lease costs and other intangibles, such as the value of leases with above or below market rents, origination costs associated with the in-place leases, the value of in-place leases and tenant relationships, if any.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P90_S1	We depreciate the amount allocated to building, deferred lease costs and other intangible assets over their estimated useful lives, which generally range from 3 to 33 years.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P91_S0	The values of the above and below market leases are amortized and recorded as either an increase (in the case of below market leases) or a decrease (in the case of above market leases) to rental income over the remaining term of the associated lease.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P91_S1	The values of below market leases that are considered to have renewal periods with below market rents are amortized over the remaining term of the associated lease plus the renewal periods.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P91_S2	The value associated with in-place leases is amortized over the remaining lease term and tenant relationships is amortized over the expected term, which includes an estimated probability of the lease renewal.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P91_S3	If a tenant vacates its space prior to the contractual termination of the lease and no rental payments are being made on the lease, any unamortized balance of the related intangibles is written off.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P91_S4	The tenant improvements and origination costs are amortized as an expense over the remaining life of the lease (or charged against earnings if the lease is terminated prior to its contractual expiration date).
1004036_11_ITEM15_P92_S0	We assess fair value based on estimated cash flow projections that utilize appropriate discount and capitalization rates and available market information.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P93_S0	Buildings, improvements and fixtures consist primarily of permanent buildings and improvements made to land such as landscaping and infrastructure and costs incurred in providing rental space to tenants.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P93_S1	Interest costs capitalized during 2010 , 2009 and 2008 amounted to approximately $1.5 million, $300,000 and $1.7 million, respectively, and internal development costs capitalized amounted to $1.5 million, $1.5 million and $1.8 million, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P93_S2	Depreciation expense related to rental property included in income from continuing oper ations for each of the years ended December 31, 2010 , 2009 and 2008 was $64.5 million, $64.5 million and $49.0 million, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P94_S0	The pre-construction stage of project development involves certain costs to secure land control and zoning and complete other initial tasks essential to the development of the project.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P94_S1	These costs are trans ferred from other assets to construction in progress when the pre-construction tasks are completed.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P94_S2	Costs of unsuccessful pre-construction efforts are charged to operations when the project is no longer probable.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P95_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents - All highly liquid investments with an original maturity of three months or less at the date of purchase are considered t o be cash equivalents.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P96_S0	Cash balances at a limited number of banks may periodically exceed insurable amounts.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P96_S1	We believe that we mitigate our risk by investing in or through major financial institutions.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P97_S0	Recoverability of investments is dependent upon the performance of the issuer.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P97_S1	At December 31, 2010 and 2009 , respectively, we had cash equivalent investments in highly liquid money market accounts at major financial institutions of $550,000 and $750,000, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P98_S0	Deferred Charges - Deferred charges includes deferred lease costs and other intangible assets consisting of fees and costs incurred to originate operating leases and are amortized over the average minimum lease term of 5 years.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P98_S1	Deferred lease costs capitalized, including internal lease costs and amounts paid to third-party brokers, during 2010, 2009 and 2008 were approximately $6.1 million, $4.3 million and $4.6 million, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P98_S2	Deferred lease costs and other intangible assets also include the value of leases and origination costs deemed to have been acquired in real estate acquisitions.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P98_S3	See Rental Property above for a discussion.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P99_S0	Deferred financing costs include fees and costs incurred to obtain long-term financing and are amortized over the terms of the respective loans using the straight line method which approximates the effective interest method.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P99_S1	Unamortized deferred financing costs are charged to expense when debt is ret ired before the maturity date.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P100_S0	Captive Insurance - Our wholly-owned subsidiary, Northline Indemnity, LLC, is responsible for losses up to certain deductible levels per occurrence for property damage (including wind damage from hurricanes) prior to third-party insurance coverage.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P100_S1	Insurance losses are reflected in property operating expenses and include estimates of costs incurred, both reported and unreported.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P101_S0	Impairment of Long-Lived Assets - Rental property held and used by us is reviewed for impairment in the event that facts and circumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P101_S1	In such an event, we compare the estimated future undiscounted cash flows associated with the asset to the asset's carrying amount, and if less, recognize an impairment loss in an amount by which the carrying amount exceeds its fair value.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P102_S0	Fair value is determined using a market approach whereby we consider the prevailing market income capitalization rates and sales data for transactions involving similar assets.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P102_S1	We recognized impairment losses of $846,000 and $5.2 million during the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P102_S2	We believe there are no unrecorded impairment losses as of December 31, 2010 .
1004036_11_ITEM15_P103_S0	Real estate assets designated as held for sale are stated at the lower of their carrying value or their fair value less costs to sell.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P103_S1	We classify real estate as held for sale when our Board of Directors approves the sale of the assets and it meets the requirements of current accounting guidance.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P103_S2	Subsequent to this classification, no further depreciation is recorded on the assets.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P103_S3	The operating results of real estate assets designated as held for sale and for assets sold are included in discontinued operations for all periods presented in our results of operations.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P104_S0	Impairment of Investments - On a periodic basis, we assess whether there are any indicators that the value of our investments in unconsolidated joint ventures may be impaired.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P104_S1	An investment is impaired only if management's estimate of the value of the investment is less than the carrying value of the investments, and such decline in value is deemed to be other than temporary.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P104_S2	To the extent impairment has occurred, the loss shall be measured as the excess of the carrying amount of the investment over the value of the investment.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P105_S0	Our estimates of value for each joint venture investment are b ased on a number of assumptions that are subject to economic and market uncertainties including, among others, demand for space, competition for tenants, changes in market rental rates and operating costs of the property.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P105_S1	As these factors are difficult to predict and are subject to future events that may alter our assumptions, the values estimated by us in our impairment analysis may not be realized.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P105_S2	As of December 31, 2010 , we do not believe that any of our equity investments were impaired.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P106_S0	Derivatives - We selectively enter into interest rate protect ion agreements to mitigate the impact of changes in interest rates on our variable rate borrowings.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P106_S1	The notional amounts of such agreements are used to measure the interest to be paid or received and do not represent the amount of exposure to loss.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P106_S2	None of these agreements are used for speculative or trading purposes.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P107_S0	We recognize all derivatives as either assets or liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets and measure those instruments at their fair value.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P107_S1	We also measure the effectiveness, as defined by the relevant accounting guidance, of all derivatives.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P107_S2	We formally document our derivative transactions, including identifying the hedge instruments and hedged items, as well as our risk management objectives and strategies for entering into the hedge transaction.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P107_S3	At inception and on a quarterly basis thereafter, we assess the effectiveness of derivatives used to hedge transactions.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P107_S4	If a cash flow hedge is deemed effective, we record the change in fair value in other comprehensive income.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P107_S5	If after assessment it is determined that a portion of the derivative is ineffective, then that portion of the derivative's change in fair value will be immediately recognized in earnings.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P108_S0	Income Taxes - We operate in a manner intended to enable the Company to qualify as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P108_S1	A REIT which distributes at least 90% of its taxable income to its shareholders each year and which meets certain other conditions is not taxed on that portion of its taxable income which is distributed to its shareholders.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P108_S2	We intend to continue to qualify as a REIT and to distribute substantially all of the Company's taxable income to its shareholders.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P108_S3	Accordingly, no provision has been made in the Company's consolidated financial statements for Federal income taxes.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P108_S4	As a partnership, the allocated share of income or loss for the year with respect to the Operating Partnership is included in the income tax returns for the partners; accordingly, no provision has been made for Federal income taxes in the Operating Partnership's consolidated financial statements.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P108_S5	In addition, we continue to evaluate uncertain tax positions.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P108_S6	The tax years 2007 - 2010 remain open to examination by the major tax jurisdictions to which we are subject.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P109_S0	In No vember 2005, we issued 7.5% Class C Cumulative Preferred Shares (liquidation preference $25.00 per share).
1004036_11_ITEM15_P109_S1	In 2009, we paid a cash dividend of $1.88 per share, of which $1.85 was treated as ordinary income and $.03 of which was treated as a capital gain distribution.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P109_S2	We paid preferred cash dividends per share of $2.07 and $1.88 in 2010 and 2008, respectively, all of which were treated as ordinary income.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P109_S3	In December 2010, the Company completed the redemption of all of its outstanding 7.5% Class C Cumulative Preferred Shares.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P109_S4	The initial redemption price was $25.00 per share, plus all accrued and unpaid dividends up to and including the redemption date, for a total redemption price of $25.198 per share.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P109_S5	Total cash paid to redeem the shares, plus accrued dividends, was $75.6 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P110_S0	For income tax purposes, distributions paid to the Company's common shareholders consist of ordinary income, capital gains, return of capital or a combination thereof.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P110_S1	Dividends per share were taxable as follows:
1004036_11_ITEM15_P111_S0	The following reconciles net income available to the Company's shareholders to taxable income available to common shareholders for the years ended December 31, 2010 , 2009 and 2008 :
1004036_11_ITEM15_P112_S0	Revenue Recognition - Base rentals are recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P112_S1	Straight-line rent adjustments recorded in other assets were approximately $16.7 million and $14.3 million as of December 31, 2010 and 2009 , respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P113_S0	Substantially all leases contain provisions which provide additional rents based on tenants' sales volume ( percentage rentals ) and reimbursement of the tenants' share of advertising an d promotion, common area maintenance, insurance and real estate tax expenses.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P113_S1	Percentage rentals are recognized when specified targets that trigger the contingent rent are met.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P113_S2	Expense reimbursements are recognized in the period the applicable expenses are incurred.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P113_S3	Payments received from the early termination of leases are recognized as revenue from the time the payment is receivable until the tenant vacates the space.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P114_S0	The values of the above and below market leases are amortized and recorded as either an increase (in the case of below market leases) or a decrease (in the case of above market leases) to rental income over the remaining term of the associated lease.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P114_S1	If a tenant vacates its space prior to the contractual termination of the lease and no rental payments are being made on the lease, any unamortized balance of the related above or below market lease value will be written off.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P115_S0	We provide management, leasing and development services for a fee for certain properties that we partially own through a joint venture.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P115_S1	Fees received for these services are recognized as other income when earned.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P116_S0	Concentration of Credit Risk - We perform ongoing credit evaluations of our tenants.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P117_S0	Although the tenants operate principally in the retail industry, the properties are geographically diverse.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P117_S1	No single tenant accounted for 10% or more of combined base and percentage rental income or gross leasable area during 2010 , 2009 or 2008 .
1004036_11_ITEM15_P118_S0	The Riverhead, New York center is the only property that comprises more than 10% of our consolidated gross revenues.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P118_S1	The Riverhead center, originally constructed in 1994, represented approximately 12% of our consolidated total revenues for the year ended December 31, 2010 .
1004036_11_ITEM15_P118_S2	The Riverhead center contained 729,475 square feet as of December 31, 2010 .
1004036_11_ITEM15_P118_S3	No property comprises more than 10% of our consolidated total assets.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P119_S0	Supplemental Cash Flow Information - We purchase capital equipment and incur costs relating to construction of new facilities, including tenant finishing allowances.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P119_S1	Expenditures included in construction trade payables as of December 31, 2010 , 2009 and 2008 amounted to $31.8 million, $14.2 million and $12.0 million, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P119_S2	Interest paid, net of interest capitalized, in 2010 , 2009 and 2008 was $37.6 million, $36.0 million and $40.5 million, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P119_S3	Interest paid for 2008 includes a prepayment premium for the early extinguishment of debt of approximately $406,000.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P120_S0	Non-cash financing activities that occurred during the 2009 period included the assumption of mortgage debt in the amount of $35.8 million, including a discount of $1.5 million related to the acquisition of the remaining 50% inter est in the Myrtle Beach Hwy 17 joint venture.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P120_S1	In addition, rental property increased by $32.0 million related to the fair market valuation of our previously held interest in excess of carrying amount.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P121_S0	We also completed a non-cash exchange offer, as described in Note 9, which resulted in the retirement of $142.3 million in principal amount of exchangeable notes which had a carrying value of $135.3 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P121_S1	These notes were retired concurrent with the issuance of approximately 9.7 million common shares.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P122_S0	In August 2009, we closed on the sale of an outparcel of land at our property in Washington, PA.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P122_S1	A non-cash condition of the sale was the assumption by the buyer of approximately $2.6 million of the tax increment financing liability associated with the property.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P123_S0	During the second quarter of 2008, upon the closing of our LIBOR based unsecured term loan facility, we determined that we were unlikely to enter into a US Treasury based debt offering.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P123_S1	In accordance with accounting guidance for derivatives, we reclassified to earnings in the period the amount recorded in other comprehensive income, $17.8 million, related to these derivatives.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P123_S2	This amount had been frozen as of March 31, 2008 when we determined that the probability of the forecast transaction was reasonably possible instead of probable .
1004036_11_ITEM15_P123_S3	Effective April 1, 2008, we discontinued hedge accounting and the changes in the fair value of the derivative contracts subsequent to April 1, 2008 resulted in a gain of $8.9 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P123_S4	The accounting treatment of these derivatives resulted in a net loss on settlement of $8.9 million which has been reflected in the statement of cash flows as a non-cash operating activity.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P123_S5	The $8.9 million cash settlement of the derivatives during the second quarter was reflected in the statement of cash flows as a change in accounts payable and accrued expenses.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P124_S0	Accounting for Equity-Based Compensation - We may issue non-qualified options and other eq uity-based awards under the Amended and Restated Incentive Award Plan, or the Incentive Award Plan.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P124_S1	We account for our equity-based compensation plan under the fair value provisions of the relevant accounting guidance.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P125_S0	New Accounting Pronouncements - In December 2010, new accounting guidance was issued clarifying that the disclosure of supplementary proforma information for business combinations should be presented such that revenues and earnings of the combined entity are calculated as though the relevant business combinations that occurred during the current reporting period had occurred as of the beginning of the comparable prior annual reporting period.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P125_S1	The guidance also improves the usefuln ess of the supplementary proforma information by requiring a description of the nature and amount of material, non-recurring proforma adjustments that are directly attributable to the business combinations.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P126_S0	In November 2010, we opened our newest Tanger outlet center in Mebane, North Carolina 100% occupied.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P126_S1	The n ew center contains approximately 319,000 square feet and approximately 80 outlet tenants.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P126_S2	The total cost for the center was approximately $64.9 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P127_S0	During 2010, we began execution of a redevelopment plan for our Hilton Head I, South Carolina center.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P127_S1	The plan included a complete demolition of the existing 162,000 square foot center originally acquired in 2003.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P127_S2	The center, which is scheduled to re-open the first weekend of April 2011, will contain app roximately 176,000 square feet as well as four outparcel pads.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P127_S3	The total incremental cost for the redeveloped center is expected to be approximately $43.0 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P128_S0	During the second quarter of 2009, we completed construction of a 23,000 square foot expansion at our Commerce II, Georgia outlet center.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P128_S1	The majority of the tenants opened during the second quarter of 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P129_S0	Rental property held and used by us is reviewed for impairment in the event that facts and circumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P129_S1	In such an event, we compare the estimated future undiscounted cash flows associated with the asset to the asset's carrying amount, and if less, recognize an impairment loss in an amount by which the carrying amount exceeds its fair value.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P130_S0	In 2005, we sold our outlet center located in Seymour, Indiana but retained various outparcels of land at the development site, some of which we sold in recent years.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P130_S1	In February 2010, our Board of Directors approved the sale of the remaining parcels of land.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P130_S2	As a result of this Board approval and an approved plan to actively market the land, we accounted for the land as "held for sale" and recorded a non-cash impairment charge of approximately $735,000 in our consolidated statement of operations which equaled the excess of the carrying amount of the land over its fair value.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P130_S3	We determined the fair value using a market approach considering offers that we obtained for all the various parcels less estimated closing costs.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P130_S4	See Note 11, Fair Value Measurements, for further discussion.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P131_S0	Two of the outparcels were sold during the first half of 2010 for net proceeds of approximately $200,000 .
1004036_11_ITEM15_P131_S1	We continue to actively market the remaining parcels.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P132_S0	In May 2010, our Board of Directors approved the plan for our management to sell our Commerce I, Georgia center.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P132_S1	The majority of the center was sold in July 2010 for net proceeds of approximately $1.4 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P132_S2	The remaining portion of the center, classified as held for sale in the consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2010, was sold at the end of January 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P132_S3	During the third quarter of 2010, we recorded a non-cash impairment charge of approximately $111,000 to lower the basis of the center to its approximate fair value based on the actual sales contracts related the center.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P132_S4	In the second quarter 2009, we recorded a $5.2 million non-cash impairment charge in our consolidated statement of operations whi ch equaled the excess of the property's carrying value over its fair value at that time.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P132_S5	We determined the fair value in 2009 using a market approach whereby we considered the prevailing market income capitalization rates and sales data for transactions involving similar assets.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P133_S0	In December 2006 the Redevelopment Authority of Washington County, Pennsylvania issued tax increment financing bonds to finance a portion of the public infrastructure improvements related to the construction of the Tanger outlet center in Washington, PA.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P133_S1	We received the net proceeds from the bond issuance as reimbursement for funds expended on qualifying assets as defined in the bond agreement.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P133_S2	Debt service of these bonds is funded by 80% of the incremental real property taxes assessed within the tax increment financing district and any shortfalls in the debt service are funded by special assessments on the Washington, PA property.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P134_S0	We originally recorded in other liabilities on our consolidated balance sheet approximately $17.9 million which represents the funds that we have received and expect to receive from the bonds.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P134_S1	Associated with this liability is a discount of $5.7 million representing the difference between the amount received and the total amount of the bonds issued.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P134_S2	The principal amount of bonds issued totaled $23.6 million, mature in July 2035 and bear interest at an effective rate of 7.81% and a stated rate of 5.45%.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P134_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2010 , approximately $1.2 million of interest expense related to this bond is included in the consolidated statement of operations.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P134_S4	As of December 31, 2010 the bonds had a net carrying amount of $15.3 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P135_S0	As discussed in Note 6, a portion of the bonds totaling $2.6 million was assumed by the buyer in an outparcel sale transaction in August 2009.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P135_S1	Estimated principal reductions in aggregate over the next 5 years are expected to be $1.0 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P136_S0	During 2009, we obtained approval from Beaufort County, South Carolina to implement a redevelopment plan at the Hilton Head I, SC outlet cente r. Based on the redevelopment timeline, we intended to demolish the existing buildings during the second quarter of 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P136_S1	Therefore, we changed the estimated useful lives of the depreciable assets to end at the date the center was expected to be vacant in preparation for demolition.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P136_S2	As a result of this change in useful lives, additional depreciation and amortization of approximately $9.0 million and $6.3 million was recognized during the 2010 and 2009 period, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P136_S3	The accelerated depreciation and amortization reduced income from continuing operations and net income by approximately $.10 and $.08 per share for the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P136_S4	Once the demolition was completed during the second quarter of 2010, the fully depreciated assets were written-off.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P142_S0	In October 2003, we, and two other members each having a 33.3% ownership interest, established a joint venture to develop and own a shopping center in Deer Park, New York.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S0	In May 2007, the joint venture closed on the project financing which is structured in two parts.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S1	The first is a $269.0 million loan collateralized by the property as well as limited joint and several guarantees by all three venture partners.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S2	These guarantees require the venture partners to cover any operating costs shortfalls, if any, including property taxes and interest costs but do not include any guarantee of loan principal.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S3	In addition, a completion guarantee remains in effect for the final construction phase of the center.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S4	The second is a $15.0 million mezzanine loan secured by the pledge of the partners' equity interests.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S5	The weighted average interest rate on the financing is one month LIBOR plus 1.49%.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S6	Over the life of the loans, if certain criteria are met, the weighted average interest rate can decrease to one month LIBOR plus 1.23%.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S7	The loans had a combined balance $266.9 million as of December 31, 2010 and are scheduled to mature in May 2011 with a one year extension option at that date.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S8	The extension option is contingent upon the joint venture property meeting certain financial and operational levels and thresholds.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S9	Based on the current cash flows and occupancy rate, the joint venture would not qualify for the one-year extension option and is currently in negotiations with the lending institution to refinance the existing loan.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P143_S10	If the joint venture is unable to extend or refinance the l oan, each joint venture partner may be required to make a material capital contribution.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P144_S0	In June 2009, the two interest rate swaps entered into by Deer Park in 2007 with a notional amount totaling $170.0 million that had fixed the LIBOR index at an average of 5.38% related to Deer Park's $284.0 million construction loan expired.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P144_S1	At that time, a forward starting interest rate cap originally purchased by Deer Park in February 2009 at a cost approximately $290,000 replaced these interest rate protection agreements as a hedge of interest rate risk.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P144_S2	The agreement caps the 30-day LIBOR index at 4% on a notional amount of $240.0 million for a period through April 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P145_S0	In June 2008, we, and our two other partners formed a separate joint venture to acquire a 29,000 square foot warehouse adjacent to the shopping center to support the operations of the shopping center's tenants.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P145_S1	Each partner maintains a 33.3% ownership interest in this joint venture which acquired the warehouse for a purchase price of $3.3 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P145_S2	The venture also obtained $2.3 million in financing at a variable interest rate of LIBOR plus 1.85% and a maturity of May 2011 with a one year extension option at that date.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P145_S3	The extension option is contingent upon the joint venture property meeting certain financial and operational levels and thresholds.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P145_S4	Based on the current cash flows and occupancy rate, the joint venture would not qualify for the one-year extension option and is currently in negotiations with the lending institution to refinance the existing loan.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P145_S5	If the joint ve nture is unable to extend or refinance the loan, each joint venture partner may be required to make a material capital contribution.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P146_S0	During 2008, we made additional capital contributions of $1.6 million to the Deer Park joint venture.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P146_S1	Both of the other venture partners made equity contributions equal to ours.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P146_S2	After making the above contribution, the total amount of equity contributed by each venture partner to the projects was approximately $4.8 million.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P170_S0	In June 2010, the Operating Partnership completed a public offering of $300.0 million of 6.125% senior notes due 2020 (the "2020 Notes").
1004036_11_ITEM15_P170_S1	The 2020 Notes pay interest semi-annually and were priced at 99.310% of the principal amount to yield 6.219% to maturity.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P171_S1	We used the n et proceeds from the sale of the 2020 Notes to (i) repay our $235 million unsecured term loan due in June 2011, (ii) pay approximately $6.1 million to terminate two interest rate swap agreements associated with the term loan, (iii) repay borrowings under our unsecured lines of credit and (iv) for general working capital purposes.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P172_S0	No prepayment or early termination penalty was paid as a result of the repayment of the term loan; however, unamortized loan origination costs of approximately $563,000 were written-off during the second quarter of 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P173_S0	In November 2010, the Operating Partnership entered into a $385.0 million syndicated unsecured revolving line of credit (the "Syndicated Line").
1004036_11_ITEM15_P173_S1	In addition to the Syndicated Line, the Operating Partnership simultaneously entered into a $15.0 millio n cash management line of credit with Bank of America, N.A. (the "Cash Management Line"), providing total revolving line capacity of $400.0 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P173_S2	The Cash Management Line's terms are substantially the same as the Syndicated Line, including maturity date.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P173_S3	The Syndicated Line replaces our previous $325.0 million in bilateral lines of credit that were scheduled to mature between June and August 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P173_S4	The Syndicated Line, together with the Cash Management Line, represents an increase in line capacity of more than 20%.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P173_S5	Through an accordion feature, the maximum borrowing capacity on the Syndicated Line may be increased to up to $500.0 million under certain circumstances.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P173_S6	The maturity date of the new lines is November 29, 2013, and we have an option to extend the lines for one ye ar.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P173_S7	As of the date of this filing, based on the Operating Partnership's long-term debt rating, the lines bear interest at a spread over LIBOR of 1.90% and require the payment of an annual facility fee of 0.40% on the total committed amount.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P177_S0	We are exposed to various market risks, including changes in interest rates.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P178_S0	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market rates and prices, such as interest rates.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P178_S1	We may periodically enter into certain interest rate protection and interest rate swap agreements to effectively convert floating rate debt to a fixed rate basis.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P178_S2	We do not enter into derivatives or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P179_S0	In accordance with our derivatives policy, all derivatives are assessed for effectiveness at the time the contracts are entered into and are assessed for effectiveness on an on-going basis at each quarter end.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P179_S1	All of our derivatives have been designated as cash flow hedges.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P179_S2	Unrealized gains and losses related to the effective portion of our derivatives are recognized in other comprehensive income and gains or losses related to ineffective portions are recognized in the income statement.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P180_S0	In our March 31, 2008 assessment of the two US treasury rate lock derivatives, we concluded that as of March 31, 2008, the occurrence of the forecasted transactions were considered reasonably possible instead of probable .
1004036_11_ITEM15_P180_S1	Accordingly, amounts previously deferred in other comprehensive income remain frozen until the forecasted transaction either affected earnings or subsequently became not probable of occurring.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P180_S2	The value of the derivatives as of March 31, 2008 included in other comprehensive income and liabilities was $17.8 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P180_S3	Also, hedge accounting was discontinued going forward and changes in fair value related to these two derivatives after April 1, 2008 were recognized in the statement of operations immediately.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P181_S0	In conjunction with the closing of the unsecured term loan facility discussed above, we settled two interest rate lock protection agreements which were intended to fix the US Treasury index at an average rate of 4.62% for an aggregate amount of $200.0 million of new debt for 10 years from July 2008.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P181_S1	We originally entered into these agreements in 2005 in anticipation of executing a public debt offering during 2008 that would be based on the 10 year US Treasury rate.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P181_S2	Upon the closing of the LIBOR based unsecured term loan facility, we determined that we were unlikely to execute a US Treasury based debt offering.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P181_S3	The settlement of the interest rate lock protection agreements, at a total cost of $8.9 million, was reflected as a loss on termination of derivatives in our consolidated statements of operations.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P182_S0	In July 2008 and September 2008, we entered into LIBOR based interest rate swap agreements with Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. and BB T for notional amounts of $118.0 million and $117.0 million respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P182_S1	The purpose of these swaps was to fix the interest rate on the $235.0 million outstanding under the term loan facility completed in June 2008.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P182_S2	The swaps fixed the one month LIBOR rate at 3.605% and 3.70%, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P182_S3	When combined with the current spread of 160 basis points, which can vary based on changes in our debt ratings, these swap agreements fixed our interest rate on the $235.0 million of variable rate debt at 5.25% until April 1, 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P182_S4	In the second quarter of 2010 we paid $6.1 million to terminate the two interest rate swaps because the underlying debt for the derivative transaction was repaid with a portion of the proceeds from the $300.0 million bond offering.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P182_S5	The payment was reflected as a loss on termination of derivatives in our consolidated statements of operations.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P186_S0	This note contains required fair value disclosures for certain assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring and non-recurring basis.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P187_S0	We are exposed to various market risks, including changes in interest rates.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P187_S1	We periodica lly enter into certain interest rate protection agreements to effectively convert floating rate debt to a fixed rate basis and to hedge anticipated future financings similar to those described in Note 10.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P187_S2	These instruments are required to be measured at fair value on a recurring basis.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P188_S0	In addition, rental property is considered a nonfinancial asset and the testing of it for impairment is considered nonrecurring in nature.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P189_S0	Effective January 1, 2009, the definition of fair value in the context of an impairment evaluation became the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P190_S0	Fair value guidance establishes a three-tier fair value hierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used in measuring fair value.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P190_S1	These tiers are defined as follows:
1004036_11_ITEM15_P191_S0	The valuation of our financial instruments is determined using widely accepted valuation techniques including discounted cash flow analysis on the expected cash flows of each derivative.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P191_S1	This analysis reflects the contractual terms of the derivatives, including the period to maturity, and uses observable market-based inputs, including interest rate curves.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P191_S2	The valuation also includes a discount for counterparty risk.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P192_S0	We have determined that our derivative valuations are classified in Level 2 of the fair value hierarchy.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P193_S0	For assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis, quantitative disclosure of the fair value for each major category of assets and liabilities is presented below:
1004036_11_ITEM15_P194_S0	Significant unobservable inputs Level 3 Liabilities:
1004036_11_ITEM15_P195_S0	(1) We were not a party to any derivative financial instruments as of December 31, 2010.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P196_S0	Significant unobservable inputs Level 3 Liabilities:
1004036_11_ITEM15_P197_S0	(2) Included in "Other liabilities" in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P198_S0	The estimated fair value of our debt, consisting of senior unsecured notes, exchangeable notes, unsecured term credit facilities and unsecured lines of credit, at December 31, 2010 and 2009 was $770.1 million and $567.0 million, respectively, and its recorded value was $714.6 million and $584.6 million, respectively.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P198_S1	Fair values were determined, based on level 2 inputs, using discounted cash flow analysis with an interest rate or credit spread similar to that of current market borrowing arrangements.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P199_S0	In December 2010, the Company completed the redemption of all of its outstanding 7.5% Class C Cumulative Preferred Shares.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P199_S1	The initial redemption price was $25.00 per share, plus all accrued and unpaid dividends up to and including the redemption date, for a total redemption price of $25.198 per share.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P199_S2	Total cash paid to redeem the shares, plus accrued dividends, was $75.6 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P200_S0	In May 2009, exchangeable notes of the Operating Partnership, originally issued in August 2006, in the principal amount of $142.3 million were exchanged for common shares of the Company, representing approximately 95.2% of the total exchangeable notes outstanding prior to the exchange offer.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P200_S1	In the aggregate, the exchange offer resulted in the issuance of 9,734,876 common shares and the payment of approximately $1.2 million in cash for accrued and unpaid interest and in lieu of fractional shares.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P200_S2	Following settlement of the exchange offer, exchangeable notes in the principal amount of approximately $7.2 million remained outstanding.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P200_S3	In connection with the exchange offer, we recognized in income from continuing operations and net income a gain on early extinguishment of debt in the amount of $10.5 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P200_S4	A portion of the debt discount recorded amounting to approximately $7.0 million was written-off as part of the transaction.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P201_S0	In August 2009, the Company completed a common share offering of 6,900,000 shares at a price of $17.75 per share, with net proceeds of approximately $116.8 million.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P201_S1	We used the net proceeds to repay borrowings under our unsecured lines of credit and for general corporate purposes.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P202_S1	Accordingly, 12,133,220 common shares are reserved for the potential exchange of Operating Partnership units.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P205_S0	The following table sets forth a reconciliation of the numerators and denominators in computing earnings per share for the years ended December 31, 2010 , 2009 and 2008 (in thousands, except per share amounts).
1004036_11_ITEM15_P205_S1	Note that per share amounts have been restated to reflect a two-for-one s plit of the Company's common shares in January 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P206_S0	The exchangeable notes are included in the diluted earnings per share computation, if the effect is dilutive, using the treasury stock method.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P206_S1	In applying the treasury stock method, the effect will be dilutive if the average market price of our common shares for at least 20 trading days in the 30 consecutive trading days at the end of each quarter is higher than the exchange price of $17.87 per share.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P207_S0	The computation of diluted earnings per share excludes options to purchase common shares when the exercise price is greater than the average market price of the common shares for the period.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P207_S1	No options were excluded from the 2010, 2009 or 2008 computations.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P207_S2	The assumed conversion of the partnership units held by the nonc ontrolling interest limited partner as of the beginning of the year, which would result in the elimination of earnings allocated to the minority interest in the Operating Partnership, would have no impact on earnings per share since the allocation of earnings to a partnership unit, as if converted, is equivalent to earnings allocated to a common share.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P208_S0	The Company's unvested restricted share awards contain non-forfeitable rights to dividends or dividend equivalents.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P208_S1	The impact of the unvested restricted share awards on earnings per share has been calculated using the two-class method whereby earnings are allocated to the unvested restricted share awards based on dividends declared and the unvested restricted shares' participation rights in undistributed earnings.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P208_S2	The notional units are considered contingently issuable common shares and are included in earnings per share if the effect is dilutive using the treasury stock method.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P208_S3	The notional units were issued in January 2010 and all have been excluded from the computation of diluted earnings per share for the year ended December 31, 2010 as none of the contingent conditions were satisfied as of the end of the reporting period.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P217_S0	We have a shareholder approved share-based compensation plan, the Amended and Restated Incentive Award Plan of Tanger Factory Outlet Centers and Tanger Properties Limited Partnership (the "Plan"), which covers our independent directors, officers and our employees.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P217_S1	We may issue up to 15.4 million common shares under the Plan.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P217_S2	Through December 31, 2010 , we had granted 5,049,960 options, net of options forfeited, and 2,457,420 restricted share awards, net of restricted shares forfeited, and notional units which may result in the issuance of a maximum of 1,230,000 common shares.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P217_S3	Shares remaining available for future issuance totaled 4,260,620 common shares.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P217_S4	The amount and terms of the awards granted under the Plan are determined by the Share and Unit Option Committee of the Board of Directors.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P218_S0	All non-qualified options granted under the Plan expire 10 years from the date of grant and 20% of the options become exercisable in each of the first five years commencing one year from the date of grant.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P219_S0	Options are generally granted with an exercise price equal to the market price of our common shares on the day of grant.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P219_S1	Units received upon exercise of unit options are exchangeable for common shares.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P219_S2	There were no option grants in 2010 , 2009 and 2008 .
1004036_11_ITEM15_P220_S0	During 2010 , 2009 and 2008 , the Board of Directors approved the grant of 312,720, 415,000 and 380,000 restricted shares, respectively, to the independent directors and the senior executive officers.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P220_S1	The independent directors' restricted shares vest ratably over a three year period and the senior executive officers' restricted shares vest ratably over a five year period.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P220_S2	For all of the restricted awards described above, the grant date fair value of the award was determined based upon the market price of our common shares on the date of grant and the associated compensation expense is being recognized in accordance with the vesting schedule of each grant.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P221_S0	Also during the first quarter of 2010, the Company's Compensation Committee Approved the general terms of the Tanger Factory Outlet Centers, Inc. 2010 Multi-Year Performance Plan, (the "2010 Multi Year Perform ance Plan").
1004036_11_ITEM15_P221_S1	Under the 2010 Multi-Year Performance Plan, we granted 410,000 notional units to award recipients as a group.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P222_S0	If the Company's aggregate share price appreciation during the four year period beginning January 1, 2010 equals or exceeds the minimum threshold of 40%, then the notional units will convert into the Company's restricted common shares on a one-for-one basis.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P222_S1	The notional units will convert into restricted common shares on a one-for-two basis if the share price appreciation exceeds the target threshold of 50% and on a one-for-three basis if the share price appreciation exceeds the maximum of 60%.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P222_S2	The notional amounts will convert on a pro-rata basis between share price appreciation thresholds.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P222_S3	The share price targets will be reduced on a dollar-for-dollar basis with respect to any dividend payments made during the measurement period, subject to a minimum level price target.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P222_S4	For notional amounts granted in 2010, any shares earned on December 31, 2013 will vest on December 31, 2014 co ntingent on continued employment through the vesting date.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P223_S0	The notional units, prior to the date they are converted into restricted common shares, will not entitle award recipients to receive any dividends or other distributions.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P223_S1	If the notional units are earned, and thereby converted into restricted common shares, then award recipients will be entitled to receive a payment of all dividends and other distributions that would have been paid had the number of earned common shares been issued at the beginning of the performance period.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P223_S2	Thereafter, dividends and other distributions will be paid currently with respect to all restricted common shares that were earned.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P224_S0	At the end of the four-year performance period, if the minimum share price threshold is not achieved but the Company's share performance exceeds the 50th percentile of the share performance of its peer group, the notional units will convert into restricted common shares on a one-for-one basis.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P224_S1	All determinations, interpretations and assumptions relating to the vesting and calculation of the performance awards will be made by the Company's Compensation Committee.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P254_S0	During the third quarter of 2010, Stanley K. Tanger, our founder, transferred his general partnership interest in the Tanger Family Limited Partnership, to the Stanley K. Tanger Marital Trust.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P254_S1	As discussed in Note 2, the Tanger Family Limited Partnership is the noncontrolling interest in the Company's consolidated financial statements.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P254_S2	The sole trustee of the Stanley K. Tanger Marital Trust, and thus effectively the general partner of Tanger Family Limited Partnership, is John H. Vernon.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P254_S3	Mr. Vernon is a partner at the law firm of Vernon, Vernon, Wooten, Brown, Andrews Garrett, or the Vernon Law Firm, which has served as the principal outside counsel of the Company and Operating Partnership since their inception in 1993.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P254_S4	Based on Mr. Vernon's new position as trustee of the Stanley K. Tanger Marital Trust, the general partner of the Tanger Family Limited Partnership, he is now considered a related party.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P254_S5	Ho wever, Mr. Vernon has neither ownership rights nor economic interests in either the Tanger Family Limited Partnership or the Stanley K. Tanger Marital Trust.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P256_S0	In January 2011, Kevin M. Dillon, Senior Vice President - Construction and Development, announced his resignation from the Company effective in April 2011.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P256_S1	Mr. Dillon served in different construction and development related capacities for over 17 years with the Company.

1004036_11_ITEM15_P257_S0	In January 2011, we announced that we entered into a letter of intent with RioCan Real Estate Investment Trust to form an exclusive joint venture for the acquisition, development and leasing of sites across Canada that are suitable for development or redevelopment as outlet shopping centers similar in concept and design to those within our existing U.S. portfolio.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P257_S1	Any projects developed will be co-owned on a 50/50 basis and will be branded as Tanger Outlet Centers.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P257_S2	We have agreed to provide leasing and marketing services to the venture and RioCan will provide development and property management services.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P257_S3	It is the intention of the joint venture to develop as many as 10 to 15 outlet centers in larger urban markets and tourist areas across Canada, over a five to seven year period.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P258_S0	The typical size of a Tanger Outlet Center is approximately 350,000 square feet dependent on the individual market and tenant demand.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P258_S1	Assuming these parameters are suitable and materialize in Canada, the overall investment of the joint venture is anticipated to be as high as $1 billion, on a fully built out basis,.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P259_S0	There can be no assurance that the joint venture will be consummated, or even if the joint venture is consummated that the current plans of the joint venture will be realized.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P260_S0	In January 2011, we closed on the sale of the final portion of our Commerce I, Georgia center.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P260_S1	Net proceeds from the sale were approximately $724,000.
1004036_11_ITEM15_P260_S2	There was no gain or loss on the sale as the impairment charge recorded during the third quarter of 2010 reduced the basis in the remaining property to its approximate fair value.
