1004036_12_ITEM7_P19_S0	GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES General and administrative expenses increased $5.6 million , or 23% , in the 2011 period as compared to the 2010 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P19_S1	This increase was primarily due to additional share-based compensation expense related to the 2011 restricted share grant to directors and certain officers of the Company and organizational costs related to the formation of additional unconsolidated joint ventures.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P19_S2	Also, the 2011 period included higher payroll related expenses on a comparative basis to the 2010 period due to the addition of new employees throughout 2011, including the positions of Executive Vice President - Chief Operating Officer and Executive Vice President - General Counsel.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P20_S0	The 2011 period includes costs related to the acquisition of the properties described above in "General Overview".
1004036_12_ITEM7_P21_S0	In 2005 we sold an outlet center located in Seymour, Indiana.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P21_S1	We retained various outparcels of land at the development site, some of which we had sold in recent years.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P21_S2	In February 2010, our Board of Directors approved the sale of the remaining parcels of land in Seymour, IN.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P21_S3	As a result of this Board approval and an approved plan to actively market the land, we accounted for the land as "held for sale" and recorded a non-cash impairment charge of approximately $735,000 in the 2010 period in our consolidated statement of operations which equaled the excess of the carrying amount of the land over its current fair value.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P21_S4	We determined the estimated fair value using a market approach considering offers that we obtained for all the various parcels less estimated closing costs.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P22_S0	DEPRECIATION AND AMORTIZATION Depreciation and amortization increased $6.0 million , or 8% , in the 2011 period as compared to the 2010 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P22_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in various components of depreciation and amortization (in thousands):
1004036_12_ITEM7_P23_S0	Depreciation and amortization costs increased in the 2011 period compared to the 2010 period primarily as a result of the additional centers added to the portfolio during 2011.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P23_S1	The depreciation and amortization from acquisitions includes the amortization of lease related intangibles recorded as part of the acquisition price of the acquired properties which are amortized over shorter lives.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P23_S2	In addition, the 2011 period includes a full year of depreciation and amortization related to the Mebane, NC outlet center which opened in November 2010.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P24_S0	As of March 31, 2010, the previously existing Hilton Head I, SC outlet center was vacant of all tenants in preparation for the demolition and redevelopment of the center.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P24_S1	At that point the depreciable assets of the center had been fully depreciated.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P25_S0	INTEREST EXPENSE Interest expense increased approximately $11.3 million , or 33.0% , in the 2011 period compared to the 2010 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P25_S1	The primary reason for the increase in interest expense was an increase in the average amount of debt outstanding from approximately $649.6 million for the 2010 period to approximately $870.1 million for the 2011 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P25_S2	The higher debt levels outstanding were a result of the mortgages assumed as part of the acquisition of four properties, additional funding necessary for the development and acquisition projects described above, the repurchase of 3.0 million preferred shares in December 2010 and other general corporate purposes.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P26_S0	LOSS ON EARLY EXTINGUISHMENT OF DEBT The 2010 period includes the write-off of approximately $563,000 of unamortized loan origination costs.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P26_S1	These assets were written-off due to the repayment of the $235.0 million term loan facility in the 2010 period with a portion of the proceeds from the $300.0 million unsecured bond offering in June 2010.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P27_S0	LOSS ON TERMINATION OF DERIVATIVES During the second quarter of 2010, we terminated two interest rate swap agreements with a total notional amount of $235.0 million originally entered into in 2008 for the purpose of fixing the LIBOR based interest rate on the $235.0 million term loan facility originally completed in June 2008.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P27_S1	We paid approximately $6.1 million to terminate the two interest rate swap agreements.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P27_S2	The agreements were terminated because the underlying debt for the derivative transaction was repaid with a portion of the proceeds from the $300.0 million bond offering mentioned above.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P28_S0	EQUITY IN LOSSES OF UNCONSOLIDATED JOINT VENTURES Equity in losses of unconsolidated joint ventures increased approximately $1.1 million , or 237.3% , in the 2011 period compared to the 2010 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P28_S1	Losses were higher in the 2011 period due to the increase in interest rates upon the refinancing for the Deer Park mortgage and mezzanine loans.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P28_S2	Even though the loans were refinanced in December 2011, the interest rate increase was effective as of May 2011 when the original loan terms expired.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P28_S3	In addition, in December 2011 Deer Park Warehouse recorded an impairment charge of approximately $900,000, of which our one-third share is $300,000, to lower the basis of the warehouse to its estimated fair market value.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P28_S4	The 2010 period included no impairment charges for any unconsolidated joint ventures.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P29_S0	DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS In May 2010, the Company's Board of Directors approved the plan for our management to sell our Commerce I, Georgia center.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P29_S1	The facts and circumstances of the plan met the accounting requirements to classify the results of operations of the center as discontinued operations for the 2010 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P30_S0	In the 2010 period the majority of the Commerce I, GA center was sold.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P30_S1	During the third quarter of 2010, we recorded an impairment of approximately $111,000 to lower the basis of the remaining portion of the center to its approximate fair value.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P30_S2	The remaining portion of the center was sold during the first quarter of 2011, however, the 2011 period did not include any discontinued operations.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P31_S0	NET INCOME Net income decreased approximately $29.3 million in the 2010 period to $38.3 million as compared to $67.5 million for the 2009 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P31_S1	The 2009 period included a gain on fair value measurement of previously held interest in acquired joint venture of $31.5 million and a $10.5 million gain on debt extinguishment compared to $6.7 million of losses on debt extinguishment and termination of derivatives in the 2010 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P31_S2	Net income was affected by an increase of $5.7 million in operating revenues, a $2.8 million decrease in operating expenses, a $1.9 million decrease in depreciation and amortization and a $3.6 million decrease in interest expense.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P32_S0	BASE RENTALS Base rentals increased $ 4.9 million , or 3%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P32_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in various components of base rentals from 2009 to 2010 (in thousands):
1004036_12_ITEM7_P33_S0	Base rental income generated from existing properties in our portfolio increased due to increases in rental rates on lease renewals and incremental rents from re-tenanting vacant space.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P34_S0	In November 2010, we opened our new outlet center in Mebane, NC and during the second quarter of 2009 opened an additional expansion phase at our Commerce II, GA outlet center.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P35_S0	During the second quarter of 2010, we completed the demolition of one of our two centers in Hilton Head, SC comprising approximately 162,000 square feet.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P36_S0	The redevelopment of this site began during the second quarter of 2010 with the opening of a new 177,000 square foot outlet center during the first quarter of 2011.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P36_S1	Base rentals related to the demolished center of $400,000 and $1.8 million for the years ended 2010 and 2009, respectively are included in the "Base rentals from new developments" line item above.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P37_S0	Also, included in base rentals is the amortization from the value of the above and below market leases recorded as a result of our property acquisitions as either an increase (in the case of below market leases) or a decrease (in the case of above market leases) to rental income over the remaining term of the associated lease.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P37_S1	At December 31, 2010, the net liability representing the amount of unrecognized combined above and below market lease values totaled approximately $1.5 million.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P37_S2	If a tenant vacates its space prior to the contractual termination of the lease and no rental payments are being made on the lease, any unamortized balance of the related above or below market lease value will be written off and could materially impact our net income positively or negatively.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P38_S0	PERCENTAGE RENTALS Percentage rentals, which represent revenues based on a percentage of tenants' sales volume above predetermined levels, increased $1.1 million, or 16% from the 2009 period to the 2010 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P38_S1	The increase in percentage rentals are directly related to the strength of our tenants' sales.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P38_S2	Reported tenant comparable sales for our wholly owned properties for the year ended December 31, 2010 increased 6.6% to $354 per square foot.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P38_S3	Reported tenant comparable sales is defined as the weighted average sales per square foot reported in space open for the full duration of each comparison period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P39_S0	EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENTS Expense reimbursements increased $2.1 million , or 3%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P39_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in various components of expense reimbursements from 2009 to 2010 (in thousands):
1004036_12_ITEM7_P40_S0	Expense reimbursements, which represent the contractual recovery from tenants of certain common area maintenance, insurance, property tax, promotional, advertising and management expenses, generally fluctuate consistently with the reimbursable property operating expenses to which they relate.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P41_S0	In November 2010, we opened our new outlet center in Mebane, NC and during the second quarter of 2009 opened an additional expansion phase at our Commerce II, GA outlet center.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P42_S0	Expense reimbursements from the redevelopment of Hilton Head I, SC center of $115,000 and $918,000 for the years ended 2010 and 2009, respectively, are included in the "Expense reimbursements from new developments" line item above.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P43_S0	OTHER INCOME Other income decreased $2.5 million, or 22%, in the 2010 period as compared to the 2009 period due primarily to the $3.3 million gain on the sale of a land outparcel at our Washington, Pennsylvania outlet center in August 2009.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P43_S1	This decrease was partially offset by the incremental other income generated from the opening of the outlet center in Mebane, NC in November 2010 and an increase in Tanger Club memberships and other vending categories.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P44_S0	PROPERTY OPERATING EXPENSES Property operating expenses increased $5.6 million, or 6%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P44_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in various components of property operating expenses from 2009 to 2010 thousands):
1004036_12_ITEM7_P45_S0	The increase in existing property operating expenses is primarily due to increases in snow removal in 2010 due to extreme winter weather in December in the eastern portion of the United States and normal annual increases associated with operating mall offices throughout our portfolio.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P46_S0	GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES General and administrative expenses decreased $8.0 million, or 25%, in the 2010 period as compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P47_S0	Effective September 1, 2009, Stanley K. Tanger, founder of the Company, retired as an employee of the Company.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P47_S1	His severance, totaling $10.3 million, consisted of a cash payment of $3.4 million and $6.9 million of share-based compensation from the accelerated vesting of restricted common shares.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P47_S2	Excluding this severance, general and administrative expenses increased $2.3 million primarily as a result of additional share-based compensation expense related to the 2010 notional unit plan and increases in other professional and legal fees.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P48_S0	DEPRECIATION AND AMORTIZATION EXPENSES Depreciation and amortization decreased $1.9 million, or 2%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P48_S1	The majority of the decrease is due to lower levels of intangible lease cost amortization from acquired outlet centers in 2003, 2005 and 2009.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P48_S2	These decreases were partially offset by additional depreciation and amortization of approximately $9.0 million and $6.3 million recognized during the 2010 and 2009 periods, respectively, related to the demolition and redevelopment plan at our Hilton Head I, SC center.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P49_S0	IMPAIRMENT CHARGE In 2005 we sold our outlet center located in Seymour, IN, but retained various outparcels of land at the development site, some of which we had sold in recent years.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P49_S1	In February 2010, our Board of Directors approved the sale of the remaining parcels of land in Seymour, IN.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P49_S2	As a result of this Board approval and an approved plan to actively market the land for sale, we accounted for the land as "held for sale" and recorded a non-cash impairment charge of approximately $735,000 in our consolidated statements of operations which equaled the excess of the carrying amount of the land over its fair value at that time.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P49_S3	We determined the estimated fair value using a market approach considering offers that we had obtained for all the various parcels less estimated closing costs.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P50_S0	INTEREST EXPENSE Interest expense decreased $3.6 million, or 9%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P50_S1	This decrease was due to the significant reduction in the average amount of debt outstanding through an exchange offering in May 2009 and a common share offering in August 2009.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P50_S2	These two equity transactions in essence retired approximately $259.1 million of outstanding debt.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P51_S0	The 2010 period includes the write-off of approximately $563,000 of unamortized loan origination costs.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P51_S1	These assets were written-off due to the repayment of the $235.0 million term loan facility in the 2010 period with a portion of the proceeds from the 2020 Notes.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P51_S2	In May 2009, senior exchangeable notes of the Operating Partnership in the principal amount of $142.3 million and a carrying amount of $135.3 million were exchanged for common shares of the Company, representing approximately 95.2% of the total senior exchangeable notes outstanding prior to the exchange offer.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P51_S3	In the aggregate, the exchange offer resulted in the issuance of approximately 9.7 million common shares and the payment of approximately $1.2 million in cash for accrued and unpaid interest and in lieu of fractional shares.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P51_S4	Following settlement of the exchange offer, senior exchangeable notes in the principal amount of approximately $7.2 million remained outstanding.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P51_S5	In connection with the exchange offering, we recognized in income from continuing operations and net income a gain on early extinguishment of debt in the amount of $10.5 million.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P52_S0	LOSS ON TERMINATION OF DERIVATIVES During the second quarter of 2010, we terminated two interest rate swap agreements with a total notional amount of $235.0 million.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P52_S1	These agreements were originally entered into in 2008 for the purpose of fixing the LIBOR based interest rate on the $235.0 million term loan facility originally completed in June 2008.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P52_S2	We paid approximately $6.1 million to terminate the two interest rate swap agreements.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P52_S3	The agreements were terminated because the underlying debt for the derivative transaction was repaid with a portion of the proceeds from the 2020 Notes.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P53_S0	Prior to when they were terminated, the swaps were designated as cash flow hedges.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P53_S1	Unrealized gains and losses related to the effective portion of the swaps were recognized in other comprehensive income.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P53_S2	Because the swaps were highly effective, the amount included in accumulated other comprehensive income when the swaps were terminated was equal to the amount recorded as a liability on the balance sheet.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P53_S3	The contemporaneous termination of the swaps and the related debt caused the amounts in accumulated other comprehensive income to be reclassified to earnings.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P53_S4	Additionally, a payment of $6.1 million, which was considered to be an investing activity in the statement of cash flows, was made to relieve the obligation that was recorded as a liability.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P54_S0	GAIN ON FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENT OF PREVIOUSLY HELD INTEREST IN ACQUIRED JOINT VENTURE On January 5, 2009, we purchased the remaining 50% interest in the Myrtle Beach Hwy 17 joint venture for a cash price of $32.0 million and the assumption of the existing mortgage loan of $35.8 million.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P54_S1	The acquisition was funded by amounts available under our unsecured lines of credit.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P54_S2	We had owned a 50% interest in the Myrtle Beach Hwy 17 joint venture since its formation in 2001 and accounted for it under the equity method.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P54_S3	The joint venture is now 100% owned by us and has been consolidated since January 2009.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P54_S4	The acquisition was accounted for under the new guidance for acquisitions which was effective January 1, 2009.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P54_S5	Under this guidance, we recorded a gain of $31.5 million which represented the difference between the fair market value of our previously owned interest and its cost basis.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P55_S0	EQUITY IN LOSSES OF UNCONSOLIDATED JOINT VENTURES Equity in losses of unconsolidated joint ventures decreased by $1.0 million, or 69%, in the 2010 period compared to the 2009 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P55_S1	The improvement is due to the natural expiration of $170.0 million of interest rate swaps at the Deer Park joint venture in June 2009.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P55_S2	The expiration of these swaps enabled the joint venture to incur interest at a variable rate based on a LIBOR index that is currently at historically low levels.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P55_S3	The decrease was offset slightly by higher interest rate levels at our Wisconsin Dells joint venture which refinanced its $24.8 million mortgage loan in December 2009.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P55_S4	The new mortgage included a credit spread over the LIBOR rate of 3.00% compared to a credit spread of 1.30% in the expiring mortgage.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P56_S0	DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS In May 2010, the Company's Board of Directors approved a plan for our management to sell our Commerce I, Georgia center.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P56_S1	The facts and circumstances of the plan met the accounting requirements to classify the results of operations of the center as discontinued operations.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P56_S2	The majority of the center was sold in July 2010.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P56_S3	The remaining portion of the center was sold during the first quarter of 2011.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P56_S4	During the third quarter of 2010, we recorded an impairment of approximately $111,000 to lower the basis of the remaining portion of the center to its approximate fair value based on the actual sales contracts related to the center.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P56_S5	In the 2009 period, we recorded an impairment charge for the Commerce I, GA property of $5.2 million which equaled the excess of the property's carrying value over its estimated fair value at that time.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P57_S0	In this Liquidity and Capital Resources of the Company section, the term, the Company, refers only to Tanger Factory Outlet Centers, Inc. on an unconsolidated basis, excluding the Operating Partnership.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P58_S0	The Company's business is operated primarily through the Operating Partnership.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P58_S1	The Company issues public equity from time to time, but does not otherwise generate any capital itself or conduct any business itself, other than incurring certain expenses in operating as a public company, which are fully reimbursed by the Operating Partnership.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P58_S2	The Company does not hold any indebtedness, and its only material asset is its ownership of partnership interests of the Operating Partnership.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P59_S0	The Company's principal funding requirement is the payment of dividends on its common shares.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P59_S1	The Company's principal source of funding for its dividend payments is distributions it receives from the Operating Partnership.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P60_S0	Through its ownership of the sole general partner of the Operating Partnership, the Company has the full, exclusive and complete responsibility for the Operating Partnership's day-to-day management and control.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P60_S1	The Company causes the Operating Partnership to distribute all, or such portion as the Company may in its discretion determine, of its available cash in the manner provided in the Operating Partnership's partnership agreement.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P60_S2	The Company receives proceeds from equity issuances from time to time, but is required by the Operating Partnership's partnership agreement to contribute the proceeds from its equity issuances to the Operating Partnership in exchange for partnership units of the Operating Partnership.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P61_S0	The Company is a well-known seasoned issuer with a shelf registration which expires in July 2012 that allows the Company to register unspecified, various classes of equity securities and the Operating Partnership to register unspecified, various classes of debt securities.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P61_S1	As circumstances warrant, the Company may issue equity from time to time on an opportunistic basis, dependent upon market conditions and available pricing.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P61_S2	The Operating Partnership may use the proceeds to repay debt, including borrowings under its lines of credit, develop new or existing properties, to make acquisitions of properties or portfolios of properties, to invest in existing or newly created joint ventures or for general corporate purposes.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P62_S0	The liquidity of the Company is dependent on the Operating Partnership's ability to make sufficient distributions to the Company.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P62_S1	The Company also guarantees some of the Operating Partnership's debt.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P62_S2	If the Operating Partnership fails to fulfill its debt requirements, which trigger the Company's guarantee obligations, then the Company may be required to fulfill its cash payment commitments under such guarantees.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P62_S3	However, the Company's only material asset is its investment in the Operating Partnership.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P63_S0	The Company believes the Operating Partnership's sources of working capital, specifically its cash flow from operations, and borrowings available under its unsecured credit facilities, are adequate for it to make its distribution payments to the Company and, in turn, for the Company to make its dividend payments to its shareholders.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P63_S1	However, there can be no assurance that the Operating Partnership's sources of capital will continue to be available at all or in amounts sufficient to meet its needs, including its ability to make distribution payments to the Company.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P63_S2	The unavailability of capital could adversely affect the Operating Partnership's ability to pay its distributions to the Company, which will in turn, adversely affect the Company's ability to pay cash dividends to its shareholders.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P64_S0	For the Company to maintain its qualification as a real estate investment trust, it must pay dividends to its shareholders aggregating annually at least 90% of its taxable income.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P64_S1	While historically the Company has satisfied this distribution requirement by making cash distributions to its shareholders, it may choose to satisfy this requirement by making distributions of cash or other property, including, in limited circumstances, the Company's own shares.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P65_S0	Based on our 2011 taxable income to shareholders, we were required to distribute approximately $54.7 million to our shareholders in order to maintain our REIT status as described above.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P65_S1	We distributed approximately $65.8 million to shareholders which significantly exceeds our required distributions.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P65_S2	If events were to occur that would cause our dividend to be reduced, we believe we still have an adequate margin regarding required dividend payments based on our historic dividend and taxable income levels to maintain our REIT status.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P66_S0	As a result of this distribution requirement, the Operating Partnership cannot rely on retained earnings to fund its on-going operations to the same extent that other companies whose parent companies are not real estate investment trusts can.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P66_S1	The Company may need to continue to raise capital in the equity markets to fund the Operating Partnership's working capital needs, as well as potential developments of new or existing properties, acquisitions or investments in existing or newly created joint ventures.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P67_S0	As the sole owner of the general partner with control of the Operating Partnership, the Company consolidates the Operating Partnership for financial reporting purposes.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P68_S0	The Company does not have significant assets other than its investment in the Operating Partnership.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P68_S1	Therefore, the assets and liabilities and the revenues and expenses of the Company and the Operating Partnership are the same on their respective financial statements, except for immaterial differences related to cash, other assets and accrued liabilities that arise from public company expenses paid by the Company.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P68_S2	However, all debt is held directly or indirectly at the Operating Partnership level, and the Company has guaranteed some of the Operating Partnership's unsecured debt as discussed below.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P69_S0	Because the Company consolidates the Operating Partnership, the section entitled Liquidity and Capital Resources of the Operating Partnership should be read in conjunction with this section to understand the liquidity and capital resources of the Company on a consolidated basis and how the Company is operated as a whole.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P70_S0	In this Liquidity and Capital Resources of the Operating Partnership section, the terms we , our and us refer to the Operating Partnership or the Operating Partnership and the Company together, as the text requires.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P71_S0	Property rental income represents our primary source to pay property operating expenses, debt service, capital expenditures and distributions, excluding non-recurring capital expenditures and acquisitions.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P71_S1	To the extent that our cash flow from operating activities is insufficient to cover such non-recurring capital expenditures and acquisitions, we finance such activities from borrowings under our unsecured lines of credit or from the proceeds from the Operating Partnership's debt offerings and the Company's equity offerings.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P72_S0	We believe we achieve a strong and flexible financial position by attempting to: (1) maintain a conservative leverage position relative to our portfolio when pursuing new development, expansion and acquisition opportunities, (2) extend and sequence debt maturities, (3) manage our interest rate risk through a proper mix of fixed and variable rate debt, (4) maintain access to liquidity by using our lines of credit in a conservative manner and (5) preserve internally generated sources of capital by strategically divesting of our underperforming assets and maintaining a conservative distribution payout ratio.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P72_S1	We manage our capital structure to reflect a long-term investment approach and utilize multiple sources of capital to meet our requirements.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P73_S0	The following table sets forth our changes in cash flows from 2011 and 2010 (in thousands):
1004036_12_ITEM7_P74_S0	Property rental income represents our primary source of net cash provided by operating activities.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P75_S0	Rental and occupancy rates are the primary factors that influence property rental income levels.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P76_S0	Cash flows provided by operating activities increased in the 2011 period compared to the 2010 period due to incremental cash flow provided by the re-opening of the Hilton Head I, SC outlet center and the outlet centers acquired during 2011.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P76_S1	In addition, the Mebane, NC outlet center was open for a full year in 2011 compared with two months in the 2010 period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P76_S2	In addition, base rental income generated from existing properties in our portfolio increased due to increases in rental rates on lease renewals and incremental rents from re-tenanting vacant spaces.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P77_S0	Cash flow used in investing activities was higher in the 2011 period mainly due to the $266.2 million expended for the acquisition of four outlet centers as well as an increase of $25.3 million in additions to unconsolidated joint ventures offset by a $6.1 million cash payment in the 2010 period to terminate certain derivative agreements.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P78_S0	The following is a summary of the 2011 and 2010 financing transactions:
1004036_12_ITEM7_P79_S0	In July 2011, the Company raised approximately $117.4 million in cash through the issuance of 4.6 million common shares.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P79_S1	The net proceeds from the offering were contributed to the Operating Partnership in exchange for 13,000 general partnership common units and 1,137,000 limited partnership common units.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P80_S0	In August 2011, the remaining outstanding $7.2 million of our senior exchangeable notes were exchanged and 136,360 Company common shares were issued to note holders in addition to the principal repayments.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P81_S0	In June 2010, the Operating Partnership issued $300.0 million of 6.125% senior notes due 2020 at a price of 99.310%.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P82_S0	In December 2010, the Company completed the redemption of all of its outstanding 7.5% Class C Cumulative Preferred Shares for a total redemption price of $25.198 per share.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P83_S0	We intend to continue to grow our portfolio by developing, expanding or acquiring additional outlet centers.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P83_S1	In the section below, we describe the new developments that are either currently planned, underway or recently completed.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P83_S2	However, you should note that any developments or expansions that we, or a joint venture that we are involved in, have planned or anticipated may not be started or completed as scheduled, or may not result in accretive net income or FFO.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P83_S3	See the section Funds From Operations in the Management's Discussion and Analysis section for further discussion of FFO.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P83_S4	In addition, we regularly evaluate acquisition or disposition proposals and engage from time to time in negotiations for acquisitions or dispositions of properties.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P83_S5	We may also enter into letters of intent for the purchase or sale of properties.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P83_S6	Any prospective acquisition or disposition that is being evaluated or which is subject to a letter of intent may not be consummated, or if consummated, may not result in an increase in liquidity, net income or funds from operations.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P84_S0	During the first quarter of 2011, we completed the redevelopment of our Hilton Head I, SC outlet center and celebrated a grand re-opening on March 31, 2011.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P84_S1	As of December 31, 2011, the 177,000 square foot center was 98% occupied.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P84_S2	In addition, the property features four pad sites, three of which were leased as of December 31, 2011.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P85_S0	We have formed joint venture arrangements to develop outlet centers that are currently in various stages of development in several markets.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P85_S1	See "Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements" for a discussion of unconsolidated joint venture development activities.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P86_S0	As of the date of this filing, we are in the initial study period of other potential developments, including sites located in Scottsdale, AZ, as well as Halton Hills and Ottawa, Ontario.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P86_S1	The Ontario sites, if developed, will be undertaken by our Canadian Joint Venture with our RioCan partner (see discussion under the caption RioCan Canadian Joint Venture in the section title "Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements").
1004036_12_ITEM7_P86_S2	We may also use joint venture arrangements to develop other potential sites in the United States.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P86_S3	There can be no assurance that any of these sites will be ultimately developed.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P87_S0	In the case of projects to be wholly-owned by us, we expect to fund these projects from amounts available under our unsecured lines of credit, but may also fund with capital from additional public debt and equity offerings.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P87_S1	For projects to be developed through joint venture arrangements, we typically use collateralized construction loans to fund a portion of the project, with our share of the equity requirements funded from sources previously described.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P88_S0	As of December 31, 2011 , 89% of our outstanding debt represented unsecured borrowings and 90% of the gross book value of our real estate portfolio was unencumbered.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P88_S1	We maintain unsecured lines of credit that provide for borrowings of up to $520.0 million.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P88_S2	The unsecured lines of credit have an expiration date of November 10, 2015 with an option for a one year extension.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P89_S0	In February 2012, the Operating Partnership closed on a seven-year $250.0 million unsecured term loan.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P89_S1	The term loan will be interest only, matures in the first quarter of 2019 and is pre-payable without penalty beginning in the first quarter of 2015.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P89_S2	Based on our current credit ratings, the new loan has an initial interest rate of LIBOR + 1.80%.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P89_S3	We used the net proceeds of the term loan to reduce the outstanding balances on our $520.0 million unsecured lines of credit.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P90_S0	In June 2011, the Operating Partnership closed on a $150.0 million senior unsecured bridge loan at an interest rate of LIBOR + 1.60% and used the proceeds from the loan to fund the acquisition of the Jeffersonville, OH outlet center.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P90_S1	In November 2011, the Operating Partnership repaid this bridge loan in conjunction with the recast of its unsecured lines of credit, as discussed below.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P91_S0	In July 2011, the Company completed a public offering of 4.6 million common shares at a price of $25.662 per share.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P91_S1	The net proceeds to the Company from the offering, after deducting estimated offering expenses, were approximately $117.4 million.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P91_S2	Net proceeds from the offering were contributed to the Operating Partnership in exchange for 13,000 general partnership common units and 1,137,000 limited partnership common units.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P91_S3	The Operating Partnership used the net proceeds from the offering to repay borrowings under its unsecured lines of credit and for general corporate purposes.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P92_S0	In association with the acquisitions disclosed in the "General Overview", the Operating Partnership assumed mortgage debt in the amount of $112.7 million , including total fair value premiums of $7.8 million .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P93_S0	On November 10, 2011, the Operating Partnership amended its $400.0 million of unsecured lines of credit, increasing the total capacity to $520.0 million (of which up to $100.0 million may be borrowed in Canadian dollars) and extending the maturity through November 10, 2015 .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P94_S0	The unsecured lines of credit include a $20.0 million liquidity line as well as a $500.0 million syndicated line.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P94_S1	The syndicated line may be increased to $750.0 million through an accordion feature in certain circumstances.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P94_S2	We have the option to extend the lines for an additional year to November 10, 2016 .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P94_S3	As of the date of this filing, based on the Operating Partnership's long-term debt rating, the lines bear interest at a credit spread over LIBOR of 1.25% and require the payment of an annual facility fee of 0.25% on the total committed amount.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P94_S4	Previously, the credit spread over LIBOR was 1.90% and the annual facility fee was 0.40% .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P94_S5	The Company guarantees the Operating Partnership's obligations under these lines.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P95_S0	In June 2010, the Operating Partnership completed a public offering of $300.0 million of 6.125% senior notes due 2020.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P95_S1	The 2020 Notes pay interest semi-annually and were priced at 99.310% of the principal amount to yield 6.219%.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P96_S0	Net proceeds from the offering, after deducting the underwriting discount and offering expenses, were approximately $295.5 million.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P96_S1	We used the net proceeds from the sale of the 2020 Notes to (i) repay our $235 million unsecured term loan due in June 2011, (ii) pay approximately $6.1 million to terminate two interest rate swap agreements associated with the term loan, (iii) repay borrowings under our unsecured lines of credit and (iv) for general working capital purposes.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P97_S0	In November 2010, the Operating Partnership entered into a $385.0 million syndicated, unsecured line of credit.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P97_S1	In addition, the Operating Partnership simultaneously entered into a $15.0 million cash liquidity line of credit with Bank of America, N.A. providing a total revolving line capacity of $400.0 million.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P97_S2	The liquidity line's terms were substantially the same as the syndicated line, including maturity date.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P98_S0	The syndicated line replaced our previous $325.0 million in bilateral lines of credit that were scheduled to mature between June and August 2011.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P98_S1	The maturity date of the lines was November 29, 2013, and we had an option to extend the lines for one year.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P98_S2	At that time, the lines bore interest at a spread over LIBOR of 1.90% and required the payment of an annual facility fee of 0.40% on the total committed amount.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P98_S3	In December 2010, the Company completed the redemption of all of its outstanding 7.5% Class C Cumulative Preferred Shares.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P98_S4	The redemption price was $25.00 per share, plus all accrued and unpaid dividends up to and including the redemption date, for a total redemption price of $25.198 per share.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P98_S5	Total cash paid to redeem the shares, plus accrued dividends, was $75.6 million.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P99_S0	We intend to retain the ability to raise additional capital, including public debt or equity, to pursue attractive investment opportunities that may arise and to otherwise act in a manner that we believe to be in the best interests of our shareholders and unit holders.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P100_S0	The Company is a well-known seasoned issuer with a shelf registration that allows us to register unspecified amounts of different classes of securities on Form S-3.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P101_S0	To generate capital to reinvest into other attractive investment opportunities, we may also consider the use of additional operational and developmental joint ventures, the sale or lease of outparcels on our existing properties and the sale of certain properties that do not meet our long-term investment criteria.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P101_S1	Based on cash provided by operations, existing lines of credit, ongoing relationships with certain financial institutions and our ability to sell debt or issue equity subject to market conditions, we believe that we have access to the necessary financing to fund the planned capital expenditures during 2012.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P102_S0	We anticipate that adequate cash will be available to fund our operating and administrative expenses, regular debt service obligations, and the payment of dividends in accordance with REIT requirements in both the short and long-term.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P102_S1	Although we receive most of our rental payments on a monthly basis, distributions to shareholders and unitholders are made quarterly and interest payments on the senior, unsecured notes are made semi-annually.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P102_S2	Amounts accumulated for such payments will be used in the interim to reduce the outstanding borrowings under our existing lines of credit or invested in short-term money market or other suitable instruments.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P103_S0	We believe our current balance sheet position is financially sound; however, due to the uncertainty and unpredictability of the capital and credit markets, we can give no assurance that affordable access to capital will exist between now and 2015 when our next significant debt maturities occur.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P103_S1	As a result, our current primary focus is to strengthen our capital and liquidity position by controlling and reducing construction and overhead costs, generating positive cash flows from operations to cover our dividend and reducing outstanding debt.

1004036_12_ITEM7_P111_S1	We have historically been and currently are in compliance with all of our debt covenants.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P111_S2	We expect to remain in compliance with all our existing debt covenants; however, should circumstances arise that would cause us to be in default, the various lenders would have the ability to accelerate the maturity on our outstanding debt.

1004036_12_ITEM7_P112_S1	Key financial covenants and their covenant levels include:
1004036_12_ITEM7_P113_S0	(1) For a complete listing of all debt covenants related to our senior unsecured notes, as well as definitions of the above terms, refer to our applicable supplemental indenture filing with the SEC.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P114_S0	We operate in a manner intended to enable us to qualify as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code, or the Code.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P115_S0	A REIT which distributes at least 90% of its taxable income to its shareholders each year and which meets certain other conditions is not taxed on that portion of its taxable income which is distributed to its shareholders.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P115_S1	Based on our 2011 taxable income to shareholders, we were required to distribute approximately $54.7 million to our shareholders in order to maintain our REIT status as de scribed above.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P115_S2	We distributed approximately $65.8 million to shareholders which significantly exceeds our required distributions.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P115_S3	If events were to occur that would cause our dividend to be reduced, we may not have an adequate margin regarding required dividend payments based on our historic dividend and taxable income levels to maintain our REIT status.

1004036_12_ITEM7_P117_S0	Each of the above ventures contain make whole provisions in the event that demands are made on any existing guarantees and other provisions where a venture partner can force the other partners to either buy or sell their investment in the joint venture.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P117_S1	Should this occur, we may be required to sell the property to the venture partner or incur a significant cash outflow in order to maintain ownership of these outlet centers.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P118_S0	In March 2005, we established the 50/50 Wisconsin Dells joint venture to construct and operate a Tanger Outlet center in Wisconsin Dells, WI.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P118_S1	In December 2009, the joint venture extended its interest-only mortgage loan totaling $25.3 million to December 2012.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P118_S2	The modified loan refinanced the original construction loan and bears interest based on the LIBOR index plus 3.00%.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P118_S3	The loan incurred by this unconsolidated joint venture is collateralized by its property as well a limited joint and several guarantee which in total is limited to interest costs plus 50% of the principal.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P118_S4	The loan currently has a balance of $24.3 million.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P119_S0	In October 2003, we and two other members each having a 33.3% ownership interest, established a joint venture to develop and own a shopping center in Deer Park, NY.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P119_S1	The center, which contains approximately 657,000 square feet, opened in October 2008.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P120_S0	On December 22, 2011, Deer Park closed on the refinancing of its mortgage and mezzanine loans.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P120_S1	At the closing, Deer Park made a payment of $20.0 million towards the principal amount of the mortgage bringing the new balance outstanding to $231.9 million .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P120_S2	The principal balance on the mezzanine loan remained at $15.0 million .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P120_S3	The new interest rates for the mortgage and mezzanine loan are LIBOR plus 3.50% and LIBOR plus 5.00% , respectively.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P120_S4	Each of the three partners made an equity contribution to Deer Park prior to closing of $6.4 million .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P120_S5	The $20.0 million principal payment was made from a combination of these three equity contributions totaling $19.2 million and cash available within Deer Park.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P120_S6	The maturity date of both the mortgage and the mezzanine loan is May 17, 2014 , however additional principal payments may be required prior to maturity if certain financial covenants are not met.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P120_S7	Such principal payments, if necessary, may require additional capital contributions to Deer Park by the partners.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P121_S0	In June 2008 , we, along with our partners in Deer Park, entered into a joint venture to purchase a 29,000 square foot warehouse adjacent to the Deer Park project described above for a total purchase price of $3.3 million .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P121_S1	Deer Park Warehouse, in which we have a 33.3% ownership interest, is an unconsolidated joint venture.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P121_S2	The interest-only mortgage loan for the warehouse matured on May 17, 2011 and the joint venture did not qualify for the one-year extension option.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P121_S3	As a result, the joint venture has accrued interest at a default rate of 8.25% from May 17, 2011 to December 31, 2011, and is currently in negotiations with the lender.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P121_S4	There can be no assurance as to the outcome of these negotiations.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P122_S0	As of December 31, 2011, the outstanding principal balance under the warehouse mortgage was $2.3 million .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P122_S1	In December 2011, the joint venture recorded an impairment charge of approximately $900,000 to lower the basis of the warehouse to its estimated fair market value.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P123_S0	In June 2011 , we announced the formation of a 50/50 joint venture with Simon Property Group, Inc. for the development of a Tanger Outlet Center south of Houston in Texas City, TX.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P123_S1	When completed, we expect that the center will feature over 90 brand name and designer outlet stores in the first phase which will contain approximately 350,000 square feet, with room to expand to approximately 470,000 square feet.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P123_S2	In July 2011 , the joint venture acquired the land underlying the site for approximately $5.6 million .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P123_S3	Ground breaking ceremonies were held on August 30, 2011.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P123_S4	As of December 31, 2011, we have contributed $7.8 million in cash to the joint venture to fund development activities.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P123_S5	We will provide property management and marketing services to the center and with our partners, will jointly provide development and leasing services.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P124_S0	During 2011 we announced the formation of an exclusive joint venture with RioCan Real Estate Investment Trust for the acquisition, development and leasing of sites across Canada that are suitable for development or redevelopment as outlet shopping centers similar in concept and design to those within our existing U.S. portfolio.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P124_S1	Through December 31, 2011, we have contributed approximately $1.0 million to fund pre-development and due diligence costs for various sites.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P124_S2	Any projects developed will be co-owned by us and RioCan on a 50/50 basis and will be branded as Tanger Outlet Centers.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P124_S3	We have agreed to provide leasing and marketing services to the venture and RioCan will provide development and property management services.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P124_S4	It is the intention of the joint venture to develop as many as 10 to 12 outlet centers in larger urban markets and tourist areas across Canada, over a five to seven year period.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P125_S0	The typical size of a Tanger Outlet Center is approximately 350,000 square feet depending on the individual market and tenant demand.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P125_S1	Assuming these parameters are suitable and materialize in Canada, the overall investment of the joint venture is anticipated to be as high as $1.0 billion, on a fully built out basis.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P125_S2	There can be no assurance that the current plans of the joint venture to develop outlet centers in Canada as described above will be fully realized.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P126_S0	On December 9, 2011 , the Canadian Joint Venture purchased the Cookstown Outlet Mall for $47.4 million , plus an additional $13.8 million for excess land upon the seller meeting certain conditions, for an aggregate purchase price of $61.2 million .
1004036_12_ITEM7_P126_S1	RioCan will provide development and property management services to this existing outlet center and we will provide leasing and marketing services.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P126_S2	In connection with the purchase, the joint venture assumed the in place financing of $29.6 million which carries an interest rate of 5.1% and matures in 2014.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P127_S0	Cookstown Outlet Mall is north of the Greater Toronto Area in Innisfil, Ontario, and contains approximately 159,000 square feet with the potential to expand to approximately 320,000 square feet.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P127_S1	This outlet center features many national retailers such as, Coach Outlet, Adidas, Tommy Hilfiger Outlet, Puma and Rockport.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P127_S2	The acquisition of this property will enable the Canadian Joint Venture to begin to implement its outlet center strategy immediately, as well as provide the flexibility to potentially expand the site into a full-scale Tanger Outlet Center.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P128_S0	In May 2011 , we announced the formation of a 50/50 joint venture agreement with The Peterson Companies for the development of Tanger Outlets at National Harbor in the Washington, D.C. area.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P129_S0	National Harbor includes fine restaurants, distinctive retail, office and residences, and a number of world-class hotels including the Gaylord National Resort and Convention Center.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P129_S1	Developed by The Peterson Companies, National Harbor comprises 350 acres of prime real estate along the scenic Potomac River in Prince George's County, MD.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P129_S2	It is anticipated that the joint venture will develop an approximately 40 acre parcel at National Harbor offering easy access to I-495, I-95, I-295 and the Woodrow Wilson Bridge.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P129_S3	The resulting Tanger Outlet Center is expected to house approximately 80 outlet designer and name brand stores in a center measuring up to 350,000 square feet.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P129_S4	In December 2011, both parties each made initial equity contributions of $850,000 to fund certain pre-development costs.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P129_S5	We will provide property management, leasing and marketing services to the joint venture.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P129_S6	We and The Peterson Companies will jointly provide site development and construction supervision services to the joint venture.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P130_S0	In February 2012, we announced plans to begin construction on Tanger Outlets Westgate, our previously announced site in Glendale, AZ.
1004036_12_ITEM7_P130_S1	Currently, we expect the outlet center to contain approximately 328,000 square feet and to be open in time for the 2012 holiday shopping season.
