1004036_15_ITEM7_P3_S0	Historical results and percentage relationships set forth in the consolidated statements of operations, including trends which might appear, are not necessarily indicative of future operations.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P4_S0	At December 31, 2014 , we had 36 consolidated outlet centers in 23 states totaling 11.3 million square feet.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P4_S1	We also had 9 unconsolidated outlet centers in 7 states or provinces totaling 2.6 million square feet.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P4_S2	The table below details our acquisitions, new developments, expansions and dispositions of consolidated and unconsolidated outlet centers that significantly impacted our results of operations and liquidity from January 1, 2012 to December 31, 2014 :
1004036_15_ITEM7_P5_S0	(1) On August 30, 2013, we acquired an additional one-third interest in Deer Park, bringing our total ownership to a two-thirds interest, for total consideration of approximately $27.9 million .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P5_S1	As a result of acquiring a controlling ownership interest, Deer Park has been consolidated in our balance sheet and statements of operations since the acquisition date.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P5_S2	The fair value of the net assets acquired, on a consolidated basis, totaled $83.8 million, consisting of $319.4 million in rental property and lease related intangibles, $2.3 million in other identifiable assets and liabilities, and $237.9 million in debt.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P5_S3	Previously Deer Park was reported within our unconsolidated portfolio of properties.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P6_S0	The following table provides information for our consolidated outlet centers regarding space re-leased or renewed during the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively:
1004036_15_ITEM7_P7_S0	(1) Excludes Lincoln City outlet center, which was sold in December 2014.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P7_S1	(2) Net average straight-line base rent is calculated by dividing the average tenant allowance costs per square foot by the average initial term and subtracting this calculated number from the average straight-line base rent per year amount.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P8_S0	The average annual straight-line base rent disclosed in the table above includes all concessions, abatements and reimbursements of rent to tenants.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P8_S1	The average tenant allowance disclosed in the table above includes landlord costs.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P9_S0	Net Income Net income decreased approximately $35.2 million in the 2014 period to $78.2 million compared to $113.3 million for the 2013 period.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P9_S1	The decrease in net income was due in part to the loss from the early redemption of our $250 million, 6.15% senior notes.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P9_S2	In November 2014, we completed a $250 million, 3.75% senior notes offering.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P9_S3	The net proceeds were used to redeem our $250 million, 6.15% senior notes due November 2015.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P9_S4	We recorded a charge of approximately $13.1 million for the early extinguishment of debt.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P9_S5	This charge was partially offset by the gain on the sale of our outlet center in Lincoln City, Oregon.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P9_S6	The net proceeds received from the sale of the property were approximately $39.0 million.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P9_S7	We recorded a gain on sale of real estate of approximately $7.5 million.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P10_S0	The decrease in net income was also due to a $26.0 million gain on a previously held interest in an acquired joint venture, which owned the property in Deer Park, New York, recorded in the third quarter of fiscal 2013, as well as $7.8 million recorded as our equity earnings of unconsolidated joint ventures related to certain transactions that occurred at Deer Park just prior to the acquisition.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P10_S1	Previously we owned a one-third interest in the Deer Park, New York property which was accounted for using the equity method of accounting.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P10_S2	The acquisition of our controlling interest on August 30, 2013 required us to consolidate the property for financial reporting purposes.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P10_S3	As a result, our consolidated statements of operations reflect all of the revenues and expenses of Deer Park since the acquisition date including the significant depreciation and amortization associated with the property, the net effect of which was a reduction in net income.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P11_S0	Base Rentals Base rentals increased $21.1 million , or 8% , in the 2014 period compared to the 2013 period.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P11_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in various components of base rentals (in thousands):
1004036_15_ITEM7_P12_S0	Base rental income generated from existing properties in our portfolio increased due to increases in rental rates on lease renewals and incremental rents from re-tenanting vacant spaces, as well as incremental base rental income from the expansions at our Branson, Charleston, Park City and Sevierville outlet centers in 2014.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P13_S0	Termination fees, which are generally based on the lease term remaining at the time of termination, increased compared to the 2013 period as the average remaining term on leases terminating early in 2014 was longer than the average remaining term of the leases terminating early in 2013.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P14_S0	At December 31, 2014 , the combined net amount of above market lease assets and below market lease liability values, recorded as a part of the purchase price of acquired properties, was a net above market lease asset totaling approximately $7.9 million .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P14_S1	If a tenant terminates its lease prior to the contractual termination of the lease and no rental payments are being made on the lease, any unamortized balance of the related above or below market lease value will be written off and could materially impact our net income positively or negatively.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P14_S2	The change in the amortization of above and below market lease values was primarily attributable to the amortization of the above market lease values recorded from the 2013 acquisition of the Deer Park, New York property.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P15_S0	Percentage Rentals Percentage rentals decreased $944,000 , or 8% , in the 2014 period compared to the 2013 period.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P16_S0	Percentage rentals represents revenues based on a percentage of tenants' sales volume above their contractual breakpoints.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P16_S1	The decrease in percentage rentals is primarily a function of tenants renewing leases with higher base rental rates, and accordingly, higher contractual breakpoints.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P16_S2	Reported tenant comparable sales for our consolidated properties for the rolling twelve months ended December 31, 2014 increased approximately 2% to $393 per square foot.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P16_S3	Reported tenant comparable sales is defined as the weighted average sales per square foot reported in space open for the full duration of each comparison period.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P27_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in various components of depreciation and amortization (in thousands):
1004036_15_ITEM7_P28_S0	Depreciation and amortization costs decreased at existing properties as certain construction and development related assets, as well as lease related intangibles recorded as part of the acquisition price of acquired properties, which are amortized over shorter lives, became fully depreciated during the reporting periods.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P29_S0	Interest Expense Interest expense increased approximately $6.3 million , or 12% , in the 2014 period compared to the 2013 period, primarily due to the acquisition of the additional ownership interest in Deer Park in August 2013.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P29_S1	With the acquisition of the additional interest in Deer Park, we consolidated the property with all of the property's debt being reflected on our consolidated balance sheet and the associated interest expense being reflected in interest expense on our consolidated operating statements since the acquisition date.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P29_S2	In addition, we issued $250 million in aggregate principal amount of 3.875% senior, unsecured notes during the 4th quarter of 2013.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P29_S3	The proceeds from these notes repaid amounts outstanding on our unsecured lines of credit which had an interest rate of approximately 1.2%.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P30_S0	Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt In November 2014, we completed a $250 million, 3.75% senior notes offering.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P30_S1	The net proceeds were used to redeem our $250 million, 6.15% senior notes due November 2015.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P30_S2	We recorded a charge of approximately $13.1 million for the make-whole premium related to the early redemption, which was completed in December 2014.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P31_S0	Gain on Sale of Real Estate In December 2014, we completed the sale of our outlet center in Lincoln City, Oregon.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P31_S1	The net proceeds received from the sale of the property were approximately $39.0 million.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P31_S2	We recorded a gain on sale of real estate of approximately $7.5 million.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P31_S3	We were not retained to provide any services to this outlet center after the sale was completed.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P32_S0	Gain on Previously Held Interest in Acquired Joint Venture In August 2013, we acquired an additional one-third ownership interest in the Deer Park property, bringing our total ownership to a two-thirds interest.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P32_S1	With the acquisition of a controlling interest, we have consolidated the property for financial reporting purposes since the acquisition date.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P32_S2	Using the step acquisition approach, we recorded a gain of approximately $26.0 million, representing the difference between the carrying value and the fair market value of our original equity interest.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P32_S3	The carrying value of our original investment in the property had been reduced over time as a result of recognizing our share of the losses generated by the property under the equity method of accounting.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P32_S4	The losses were generally the result of depreciation and amortization expense exceeding earnings before depreciation.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P32_S5	In addition, a significant portion of our original investment was returned during the period in which we held the investment due to distributions made to the owners from (1) proceeds received when permanent financing was put in place, (2) proceeds received from the settlement of a lawsuit, and (3) cash on hand immediately prior to our acquisition.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P32_S6	Accordingly, a substantial portion of the fair value of our equity interest was recognized as a gain due to the low cost basis of our equity investment balance in the property.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P33_S0	During the first quarter of 2014, we incurred property damage to our West Branch, Michigan outlet center due to a severe snow storm.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P33_S1	Our insurance policy provides us with reimbursement for the replacement cost for the damage done to this property.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P33_S2	During fiscal 2014, we recorded a casualty gain of $486,000 reflecting our expected total replacement insurance proceeds in excess of the total of the net book value written off and demolition costs incurred.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P34_S0	Equity in Earnings (Losses) of Unconsolidated Joint Ventures Equity in earnings of unconsolidated joint ventures decreased approximately $2.0 million in the 2014 period compared to the 2013 period.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P34_S1	The decrease is primarily due to transactions at the Deer Park property in 2013 prior to our acquisition of an additional one-third interest in the property and its subsequent consolidation for financial reporting purposes.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P34_S2	As a part of the refinancing of the debt at Deer Park in August 2013, a gain on early extinguishment of debt of $13.8 million was recorded.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P34_S3	In addition a lawsuit was settled which resulted in income to Deer Park of approximately $9.5 million after expenses.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P34_S4	Our one-third share of these transactions, recorded through equity in earnings prior to the acquisition, was approximately $7.8 million.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P34_S5	This decrease is partially offset by the incremental equity in earnings from the National Harbor outlet center and Charlotte outlet center which opened during the fourth quarter of 2013 and the third quarter of 2014, respectively.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P35_S0	Net Income Net income increased approximately $56.8 million in the 2013 period to $113.3 million compared to $56.5 million for the 2012 period.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P35_S1	The increase in net income was a result of a $28.0 million increase in operating revenues, a $26.0 million increase from a gain on a previously held interest in an acquired joint venture and a $14.3 million increase in equity in earnings from unconsolidated joint ventures.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P36_S0	Subsequent to the third quarter of 2012, five additional outlet centers were developed or acquired by our unconsolidated joint ventures.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P36_S1	These increases in income were partially offset by an increase in property operating expenses of $9.9 million, increase in general and administrative expenses of $1.7 million and an increase in interest expense of $1.8 million.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P40_S1	If a tenant terminates its lease prior to the original contractual termination date of the lease and no rental payments are being made on the lease, any unamortized balance of the related above or below market lease value will be written off and could materially impact our net income positively or negatively.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P40_S2	The decrease in base rent recognized from the amortization of above and below market lease values related primarily to the amortization of net above market lease assets recorded from the Deer Park acquisition.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P40_S3	In addition, several below market leases from previous acquisitions became fully amortized at the end of 2012 thus causing a decrease in base rent in the 2013 period compared to the 2012 period.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P52_S0	Interest Expense Interest expense increased approximately $1.8 million, or 4%, in the 2013 period compared to the 2012 period.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P52_S1	The primary reason for the increase in interest expense was the increase in the average amount of debt outstanding from approximately $1.1 billion for the 2012 period to approximately $1.2 billion for the 2013 period.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P52_S2	The higher debt levels outstanding were a result of fundings for additional investments in unconsolidated joint ventures in both Canada and the United States and the acquisition of the additional ownership interest in Deer Park.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P53_S0	Gain on Previously Held Interest in Acquired Joint Venture In August 2013, we acquired an additional one-third ownership interest in the Deer Park property, bringing our total ownership to a two-thirds interest.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P53_S1	With the acquisition of a controlling interest, we have consolidated the property for financial reporting purposes since the acquisition date.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P53_S2	Using the step acquisition approach, we recorded a gain of approximately $26.0 million, representing the difference between the carrying value and the fair market value of our original equity interest.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P53_S3	The carrying value of our original investment in the property had been reduced over time as a result of recognizing our share of the losses generated by the property under the equity method of accounting.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P53_S4	The losses were generally the result of depreciation and amortization expense exceeding earnings before depreciation.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P53_S5	In addition, a significant portion of our original investment was returned during the period in which we held the investment due to distributions made to the owners from (1) proceeds received when permanent financing was put in place, (2) proceeds received from the settlement of a lawsuit, and (3) cash on hand immediately prior to our acquisition.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P53_S6	Accordingly, a substantial portion of the fair value of our equity interest was recognized as a gain due to the low cost basis of our equity investment balance in the property.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P54_S0	Equity in Earnings (Losses) of Unconsolidated Joint Ventures Equity in earnings of unconsolidated joint ventures increased approximately $14.3 million in the 2013 period compared to the 2012 period.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P54_S4	Our one-third share of these transactions, recorded through equity in earnings prior to the acquisition, was approximately $7.8 million.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P54_S5	Incremental earnings from the addition of four outlet centers held in unconsolidated joint ventures to the portfolio during the fourth quarter of 2012 accounted for the remainder of the increase.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P55_S0	In this Liquidity and Capital Resources of the Company section, the term, the Company, refers only to Tanger Factory Outlet Centers, Inc. on an unconsolidated basis, excluding the Operating Partnership.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P56_S0	The Company's business is operated primarily through the Operating Partnership.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P56_S1	The Company issues public equity from time to time, but does not otherwise generate any capital itself or conduct any business itself, other than incurring certain expenses in operating as a public company, which are fully reimbursed by the Operating Partnership.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P56_S2	The Company does not hold any indebtedness, and its only material asset is its ownership of partnership interests of the Operating Partnership.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P57_S0	The Company's principal funding requirement is the payment of dividends on its common shares.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P57_S1	The Company's principal source of funding for its dividend payments is distributions it receives from the Operating Partnership.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P58_S0	Through its ownership of the sole general partner of the Operating Partnership, the Company has the full, exclusive and complete responsibility for the Operating Partnership's day-to-day management and control.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P58_S1	The Company causes the Operating Partnership to distribute all, or such portion as the Company may in its discretion determine, of its available cash in the manner provided in the Operating Partnership's partnership agreement.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P58_S2	The Company receives proceeds from equity issuances from time to time, but is required by the Operating Partnership's partnership agreement to contribute the proceeds from its equity issuances to the Operating Partnership in exchange for partnership units of the Operating Partnership.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P59_S0	The Company is a well-known seasoned issuer with a shelf registration which expires in June 2015 that allows the Company to register unspecified, various classes of equity securities and the Operating Partnership to register unspecified, various classes of debt securities.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P59_S1	As circumstances warrant, the Company may issue equity from time to time on an opportunistic basis, dependent upon market conditions and available pricing.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P59_S2	The Operating Partnership may use the proceeds to repay debt, including borrowings under its lines of credit, develop new or existing properties, to make acquisitions of properties or portfolios of properties, to invest in existing or newly created joint ventures or for general corporate purposes.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P60_S0	The liquidity of the Company is dependent on the Operating Partnership's ability to make sufficient distributions to the Company.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P60_S1	The Operating Partnership is a party to loan agreements with various bank lenders that require the Operating Partnership to comply with various financial and other covenants before it may make distributions to the Company.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P60_S2	The Company also guarantees some of the Operating Partnership's debt.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P60_S3	If the Operating Partnership fails to fulfill its debt requirements, which trigger the Company's guarantee obligations, then the Company may be required to fulfill its cash payment commitments under such guarantees.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P60_S4	However, the Company's only material asset is its investment in the Operating Partnership.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P61_S0	The Company believes the Operating Partnership's sources of working capital, specifically its cash flow from operations, and borrowings available under its unsecured credit facilities, are adequate for it to make its distribution payments to the Company and, in turn, for the Company to make its dividend payments to its shareholders.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P61_S1	However, there can be no assurance that the Operating Partnership's sources of capital will continue to be available at all or in amounts sufficient to meet its needs, including its ability to make distribution payments to the Company.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P61_S2	The unavailability of capital could adversely affect the Operating Partnership's ability to pay its distributions to the Company, which will in turn, adversely affect the Company's ability to pay cash dividends to its shareholders.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P62_S0	For the Company to maintain its qualification as a real estate investment trust, it must pay dividends to its shareholders aggregating annually at least 90% of its taxable income.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P62_S1	While historically the Company has satisfied this distribution requirement by making cash distributions to its shareholders, it may choose to satisfy this requirement by making distributions of cash or other property, including, in limited circumstances, the Company's own shares.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P63_S0	Based on our 2014 taxable income to shareholders, we were required to distribute approximately $55.8 million to our shareholders in order to maintain our REIT status as described above.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P63_S1	We distributed approximately $94.2 million to shareholders which significantly exceeds our required distributions.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P64_S0	As a result of this distribution requirement, the Operating Partnership cannot rely on retained earnings to fund its on-going operations to the same extent that other companies whose parent companies are not real estate investment trusts can.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P64_S1	The Company may need to continue to raise capital in the equity markets to fund the Operating Partnership's working capital needs, as well as potential developments of new or existing properties, acquisitions or investments in existing or newly created joint ventures.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P65_S0	As the sole owner of the general partner with control of the Operating Partnership, the Company consolidates the Operating Partnership for financial reporting purposes.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P66_S0	The Company does not have significant assets other than its investment in the Operating Partnership.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P66_S1	Therefore, assets, liabilities,revenues and expenses of the Company and the Operating Partnership are the same on their respective financial statements, except for immaterial differences related to cash, other assets and accrued liabilities that arise from public company expenses paid by the Company.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P66_S2	However, all debt is held directly or indirectly at the Operating Partnership level, and the Company has guaranteed some of the Operating Partnership's unsecured debt as discussed below.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P67_S0	Because the Company consolidates the Operating Partnership, the section entitled Liquidity and Capital Resources of the Operating Partnership should be read in conjunction with this section to understand the liquidity and capital resources of the Company on a consolidated basis and how the Company is operated as a whole.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P68_S0	In this Liquidity and Capital Resources of the Operating Partnership section, the terms we , our and us refer to the Operating Partnership or the Operating Partnership and the Company together, as the text requires.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P69_S0	Property rental income represents our primary source to pay property operating expenses, debt service, capital expenditures and distributions, excluding non-recurring capital expenditures and acquisitions.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P69_S1	To the extent that our cash flow from operating activities is insufficient to cover such non-recurring capital expenditures and acquisitions, we finance such activities from borrowings under our unsecured lines of credit or from the proceeds from the Operating Partnership's debt offerings and the Company's equity offerings.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P70_S0	We believe we achieve a strong and flexible financial position by attempting to: (1) maintain a conservative leverage position relative to our portfolio when pursuing new development, expansion and acquisition opportunities, (2) extend and sequence debt maturities, (3) manage our interest rate risk through a proper mix of fixed and variable rate debt, (4) maintain access to liquidity by using our lines of credit in a conservative manner and (5) preserve internally generated sources of capital by strategically divesting of our non-core assets and maintaining a conservative distribution payout ratio.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P70_S1	We manage our capital structure to reflect a long-term investment approach and utilize multiple sources of capital to meet our requirements.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P71_S0	The following table sets forth our changes in cash flows from 2014 and 2013 (in thousands):
1004036_15_ITEM7_P72_S0	Cash provided by operating activities increased slightly during 2014 compared to 2013.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P72_S1	In 2014, our cash provided from operating activities was positively impacted by a number of factors, including an increase in distributions received from unconsolidated joint ventures as we added three new joint venture properties and completed one significant expansion since November 2013, an increase in operating income throughout the consolidated portfolio from increases in base rental rates and an increase in operating income from the full year impact of the acquisition of a controlling interest in our Deer Park property in August 2013.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P72_S2	We have consolidated the Deer Park property's financial results since the acquisition date.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P72_S3	These increases were offset by higher interest expense incurred in 2014 due to the issuance of $250 million in aggregate principal amount of 3.875% senior, unsecured notes during the fourth quarter of 2013.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P72_S4	The proceeds from these notes repaid amounts outstanding on our unsecured lines of credit which had an interest rate of approximately 1.2%.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P72_S5	In addition, we paid a $13.1 million make whole premium and the original issue discount of $913,000 as part of the early redemption of our senior notes originally due in November 2015.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P73_S0	Cash used in investing activities increased during 2014 compared to 2013.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P73_S1	Cash used related to our additions to rental property was higher in the 2014 period compared to the 2013 period due primarily to ongoing construction of our Grand Rapids, Michigan and Foxwoods, Connecticut outlet centers, as well as expansions and renovations at existing outlet centers.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P73_S2	This was partially offset by the receipt of approximately $39.0 million in proceeds from the sale of our Lincoln City, Oregon outlet center in December 2014, lower amounts contributed to our unconsolidated joint ventures for the development of new properties and an increase in cash received from unconsolidated joint ventures that represented a return of investment, the most significant of which related to the Charlotte joint venture which closed on a mortgage loan during 2014 totaling $90.0 million and distributed net loan proceeds of $89.4 million equally to the partners.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P73_S3	The 2013 period included a similar transaction at our Galveston joint venture which closed on a mortgage loan during totaling $65.0 million and distributed the proceeds equally to the partners.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P74_S0	Cash provided by financing activities increased during 2014 compared to 2013.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P74_S1	The increase in cash provided by financing activities was primarily due to the additional financing proceeds needed to fund the investments at both the consolidated and unconsolidated joint venture levels discussed in the investing activities section above.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P74_S2	This increase was offset by an increase in the quarterly dividends paid to our common shareholders, an increase in the distributions to the noncontrolling interests in the Operating Partnership and amounts paid by us on behalf of certain employees related to income taxes from shares withheld upon vesting of equity awards.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P75_S0	In November 2014, we announced that Tanger Properties Limited Partnership, completed a public offering of $250.0 million in senior notes due 2024 in an underwritten public offering.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P75_S1	The net proceeds from the offering, after deducting the underwriting discount and offering expenses, were approximately $246.2 million .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P75_S2	We used the net proceeds from the sale of the notes to repay borrowings under our unsecured lines of credit.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P75_S3	We used the net proceeds from the sale of the notes to redeem our $250.0 million 6.15% senior notes due November 2015.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P76_S0	In November 2013, we announced that Tanger Properties Limited Partnership, completed a public offering of $250.0 million in senior notes due 2023 in an underwritten public offering.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P76_S1	The net proceeds from the offering, after deducting the underwriting discount and offering expenses, were approximately $243.6 million.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P76_S2	We used the net proceeds from the sale of the notes to repay borrowings under our unsecured lines of credit.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P77_S0	We intend to continue to grow our portfolio by developing, expanding or acquiring additional outlet centers.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P77_S1	In the section below, we describe the new developments that are either currently planned, underway or recently completed.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P77_S2	However, you should note that any developments or expansions that we, or a joint venture that we are involved in, have planned or anticipated may not be started or completed as scheduled, or may not result in accretive net income or FFO.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P77_S3	See the section Funds From Operations in the Management's Discussion and Analysis section for further discussion of FFO.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P77_S4	In addition, we regularly evaluate acquisition or disposition proposals and engage from time to time in negotiations for acquisitions or dispositions of properties.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P77_S5	We may also enter into letters of intent for the purchase or sale of properties.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P77_S6	Any prospective acquisition or disposition that is being evaluated or which is subject to a letter of intent may not be consummated, or if consummated, may not result in an increase in liquidity, net income or funds from operations.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P81_S0	The outlet center will contain approximately 313,000 square feet and will be suspended above ground to join the casino floors of the two major hotels located within the resort.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P82_S0	Along with other various on-site entertainment venues, the casinos attract millions of visitors each year.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P85_S1	The site is located 11 miles south of downtown Grand Rapids at the southwest quadrant of US-131 and 84th Street in Byron Township, Michigan with visibility from both roads.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P85_S2	The outlet center will be located approximately 30 miles east of Lake Michigan and its lakeside communities that are frequented by vacationers.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P85_S3	Currently, we anticipate the outlet center will open in the second half of 2015.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P92_S1	As a result of this transaction, we expect to record a gain of approximately $13.9 million in the first quarter of 2015, which represents the difference between the carrying value of our equity method investment and the purchase price.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P93_S0	Proceeds generated by the sale of assets or joint venture interests, if completed, will be used to fund the development projects discussed above, pay down outstanding debt and/or for other general corporate purposes.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P93_S1	We have not entered into a binding contract and have not obtained approval from our Board of Directors to sell any additional outlet centers or joint venture interests, thus we can give no assurance that any additional sales will be completed.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P94_S0	As of December 31, 2014 , unsecured borrowings represented 81% of our outstanding debt and 74% of the gross book value of our real estate portfolio was unencumbered.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P94_S1	We maintain unsecured lines of credit that provide for borrowings of up to $520.0 million and bear interest at a rate of LIBOR + 1.00%.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P94_S2	The unsecured lines of credit include a $20.0 million liquidity line and a $500.0 million syndicated line.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P94_S3	The syndicated line may be increased to $750.0 million through an accordion feature in certain circumstances.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P94_S4	The unsecured lines of credit have an expiration date of October 24, 2017 with an option for a one year extension.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P94_S5	The Company guarantees the Operating Partnership's obligations under these lines.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P95_S1	The loan initially matures on December 2017, with two one -year extension options.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P95_S2	The balance of this loan as of December 31, 2014 was $25.2 million .

1004036_15_ITEM7_P96_S1	The amendment reduced the interest rate on the loan from LIBOR + 1.60% to LIBOR + 1.05% , and the prepayment penalty was removed.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P96_S2	No other material terms of the loan were amended.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P97_S0	In November 2014, Tanger Properties Limited Partnership completed a public offering of $250.0 million in senior notes due 2024 in an underwritten public offering.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P97_S1	The notes were priced at 99.429% of the principal amount to yield 3.819% to maturity.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P97_S2	The notes will pay interest semi-annually at a rate of 3.750% per annum and mature on December 1, 2024.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P97_S3	The net proceeds from the offering, after deducting the underwriting discount and offering expenses, were approximately $246.2 million .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P97_S4	We used the net proceeds from the sale of the notes to redeem our $250.0 million 6.15% senior notes due November 2015.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P97_S5	We recorded a charge of approximately $13.1 million for the make-whole premium related to the early redemption, which was completed in December 2014.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P98_S0	In August 2013, as part of the acquisition of a controlling interest in Deer Park, we assumed a $150.0 million interest only mortgage loan, including a fair value discount of $1.6 million.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P98_S1	The loan has a 5 year term and carries an interest rate of LIBOR + 1.50%.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P98_S2	In October 2013, we entered into interest rate swap agreements to reduce our floating rate debt exposure by locking the interest rate on the $150.0 million mortgage.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P98_S3	The interest rate swap agreements fix the base LIBOR rate at an average of 1.30%, creating a contractual interest rate for the loan of 2.80% through August 2018.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P99_S0	In October 2013, we closed on amendments to our unsecured lines of credit, extending the maturity, and reducing the overall borrowing costs.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P99_S1	The maturity of these facilities was extended from November 10, 2015 to October 24, 2017 with the ability to further extend the maturity for an additional year at our option.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P99_S2	The annual commitment fee, which is payable on the full $520.0 million in loan commitments, was reduced from 0.175% to 0.15%, and the interest rate spread over LIBOR was reduced from 1.10% to 1.00% based on our current credit rating.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P100_S0	In November 2013, Tanger Properties Limited Partnership completed a public offering of $250 million in senior notes due 2023 in an underwritten public offering.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P100_S1	The notes were priced at 98.360% of the principal amount to yield 4.076% to maturity.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P100_S2	The notes will pay interest semi-annually at a rate of 3.875% per annum and mature on December 1, 2023.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P100_S3	The net proceeds from the offering, after deducting the underwriting discount and offering expenses, were approximately $243.6 million.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P100_S4	We used the net proceeds from the sale of the notes to repay borrowings under our unsecured lines of credit.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P101_S1	The term loan is interest only, matures in the first quarter of 2019 and is pre-payable without penalty beginning in the first quarter of 2015.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P101_S2	Based on our credit ratings at that time, and until amended in July 2014, the loan had an interest rate of LIBOR + 1.60%.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P110_S0	Our debt agreements contain covenants that require the maintenance of certain ratios, including debt service coverage and leverage, and limit the payment of dividends such that dividends and distributions will not exceed funds from operations, as defined in the agreements, for the prior fiscal year on an annual basis or 95% on a cumulative basis.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P110_S1	We have historically been and currently are in compliance with all of our debt covenants.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P110_S2	We expect to remain in compliance with all our existing debt covenants; however, should circumstances arise that would cause us to be in default, the various lenders would have the ability to accelerate the maturity on our outstanding debt.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P111_S0	We believe our most restrictive financial covenants are contained in our senior, unsecured notes.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P112_S0	We operate in a manner intended to enable us to qualify as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code, or the Code.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P113_S0	A REIT which distributes at least 90% of its taxable income to its shareholders each year and which meets certain other conditions is not taxed on that portion of its taxable income which is distributed to its shareholders.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P113_S1	Based on our 2014 taxable income to shareholders, we were required to distribute approximately $55.8 million to our shareholders in order to maintain our REIT status as described above.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P113_S2	We distributed approximately $94.2 million to shareholders which significantly exceeds our required distributions.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P113_S3	If in any taxable year the Company were to fail to qualify as a REIT and certain statutory relief provisions were not applicable, we would not be allowed a deduction for distributions to shareholders in computing taxable income and would be subject to U.S. federal income tax (including any applicable alternative minimum tax) on our taxable income at regular corporate rates.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P114_S0	The following table details certain information as of December 31, 2014 about various unconsolidated real estate joint ventures in which we have an ownership interest:
1004036_15_ITEM7_P115_S0	(1) Based on capital contribution and distribution provisions in the joint venture agreement, we expect our economic interest in the venture's cash flow to be greater than the ownership percentage indicated above, which in this case, states our legal interest in this venture.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P115_S1	Our economic interest may fluctuate based on a number of factors, including mortgage financing, partnership capital contributions and distributions, and proceeds from gains or losses of asset sales.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P115_S2	(2) The negative carrying value is due to the distributions of proceeds from a mortgage loan, as well as quarterly distributions of excess cash flow, exceeding the original contributions from the partners.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P116_S0	In addition, the joint venture agreements contain other provisions where a venture partner can force the other partners to either buy or sell their investment in the joint venture.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P116_S1	Should this occur, we may be required to sell the outlet center to the venture partner or incur a significant cash outflow in order to maintain ownership of these outlet centers.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P117_S0	We provide guarantees to lenders for our joint ventures which include standard non-recourse carve out indemnifications for losses arising from items such as but not limited to fraud, physical waste, payment of taxes, environmental indemnities, misapplication of insurance proceeds or security deposits and failure to maintain required insurance.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P117_S1	For construction and term loans, we may include a guaranty of completion as well as a principal guaranty ranging from 5% to 100% of principal.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P117_S2	The principal guarantees include terms for release based upon satisfactory completion of construction and performance targets including occupancy thresholds and minimum debt service coverage tests.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P117_S3	Our joint ventures may contain make whole provisions in the event that demands are made on any existing guarantees.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P118_S0	In July 2014, we opened a 398,000 square foot outlet center in Charlotte, NC that was developed through, and is owned by, a joint venture formed in May 2013.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P118_S1	The outlet center is located eight miles southwest of uptown Charlotte at the interchange of I-485 and Steele Creek Road (North Carolina Highway 160).
1004036_15_ITEM7_P118_S2	Construction of the outlet center, which commenced during the third quarter of 2013, was initially funded with equal equity contributions by the partners.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P118_S3	In November 2014, the joint venture closed on an interest only mortgage loan for $90.0 million at an interest rate of LIBOR + 1.45% .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P118_S4	The loan initially matures in November 2018, with the option to extend the maturity for one additional year.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P118_S5	The joint venture received net loan proceeds of $89.4 million and distributed them equally to the partners.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P118_S6	The loan balance as of December 31, 2014 was approximately $90.0 million .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P119_S0	During construction, we provided development services to the joint venture and joint leasing services with our partner.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P119_S1	Subsequent to the outlet center opening, our partner is providing property management, marketing and leasing services to the joint venture.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P120_S0	In October 2012, we opened an approximately 353,000 square foot outlet center in Texas City, Texas that was developed through, and is owned by, a joint venture formed in June 2011.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P120_S1	The development was initially fully funded with equity contributed to the joint venture by Tanger and its partner.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P120_S2	In July 2013, the joint venture closed on a $70.0 million mortgage loan with a rate of LIBOR + 1.50% and a maturity date of July 2017, with the option to extend the maturity for one additional year.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P120_S3	The joint venture received total loan proceeds of $65.0 million and distributed the net proceeds equally to the partners.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P120_S4	We used our share of the proceeds to reduce amounts outstanding under our unsecured lines of credit.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P120_S5	We are providing property management, marketing and leasing services to the outlet center.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P121_S0	In November 2013, we opened an approximately 339,000 square foot outlet center at National Harbor in the Washington, D.C. Metro area that was developed through, and is owned by, a joint venture formed in May 2011.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P121_S1	In November 2014, the joint venture amended the initial construction loan to increase the amount available to borrow from $62.0 million to $87.0 million and extended the maturity date until November 2019.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P121_S2	The loan still carries an interest rate of LIBOR + 1.65% .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P121_S3	At the closing of the amendment, the joint venture distributed approximately $19.0 million equally between the partners.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P121_S4	The loan balance as of December 31, 2014 was approximately $83.7 million .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P122_S0	We are providing property management, marketing and leasing services to the joint venture.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P123_S0	We have entered into a 50 /50 co-ownership agreement with RioCan Real Estate Investment Trust to develop and acquire outlet centers in Canada.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P123_S1	Under the agreement, any outlet centers developed or acquired will be branded as Tanger Outlet Centers.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P123_S2	We have agreed to provide leasing and marketing services for the outlet centers and RioCan has agreed to provide development and property management services.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P124_S0	In October 2014, the co-owners opened Tanger Outlets Ottawa, the first ground up development of a Tanger Outlet Center in Canada.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P124_S1	Located in suburban Kanata off the TransCanada Highway (Highway 417) at Palladium Drive, the outlet center currently contains approximately 288,000 square feet, with additional square footage totaling approximately 28,000 square feet related to an anchor tenant expected to be completed and opened in early 2016.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P124_S2	During the second quarter of 2013, the co-owners purchased the land for $28.7 million and broke ground on construction.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P124_S3	As of December 31, 2014, our share of the costs incurred to date for the development of the outlet center, which was funded with equity, totaled approximately $45.3 million .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P125_S0	In November 2014, the co-owners opened an approximately 149,000 square foot expansion to the existing Cookstown Outlet Mall, bringing the total square feet of the outlet center to approximately 305,000 square feet.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P126_S0	The co-owners acquired land adjacent to the existing Cookstown Outlet Mall in March 2013 for $13.8 million and commenced construction of the expansion in May 2013.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P126_S1	As of December 31, 2014, our share of the incurred costs related to the expansion and renovation of the existing outlet center, which was funded with equity, totaled approximately $27.1 million .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P127_S0	Other properties owned by the RioCan Canada co-owners include Les Factoreries Saint-Sauveur and Bromont Outlet Mall.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P128_S0	Les Factoreries Saint-Sauveur, is located northwest of Montreal adjacent to Highway 15 in the town of Saint-Sauveur, Quebec and is approximately 116,000 square feet.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P129_S0	In January 2014, we announced a joint venture arrangement to develop Tanger Outlets Savannah.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P129_S1	The outlet center will include approximately 377,000 square feet, and is located on I-95, just north of I-16 in Pooler, Georgia, adjacent to the City of Savannah, and near the Savannah International Airport.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P129_S2	As of December 31, 2014, our equity contributions totaled $45.2 million and our partner s equity contributions totaled $7.4 million .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P129_S3	Contributions we make in excess of our partners' equity contributions will earn a preferred rate of return equal to 8% from the date the contributions are made until the outlet center s grand opening date, and then 10% annually thereafter.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P130_S0	The joint venture has an interest only mortgage loan with the ability to borrow up to $93.0 million at an interest rate of LIBOR + 1.65% .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P130_S1	The loan initially matures on May 21, 2017, with two , one -year extension options.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P130_S2	As of December 31, 2014, the balance on the loan was $25.5 million .
1004036_15_ITEM7_P130_S3	We are providing development, management and marketing services to the joint venture; and with our partner, are jointly providing leasing services to the outlet center.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P131_S0	In November 2014, the joint venture completed approximately 50,000 square feet of a 78,000 square foot expansion of the existing property which upon completion will bring the total square feet of the outlet center to approximately 409,000 square feet.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P131_S1	The remaining square footage is expected to be completed and opened in the first quarter of 2015.

1004036_15_ITEM7_P131_S4	The amended and restated loan matures in June 2015 with the option to extend the maturity date for two additional years.
1004036_15_ITEM7_P131_S5	As of December 31, 2014 , the balance on the loan was $54.0 million .
